TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy advise the Senate of progress on the review of the current policy on the export of merino sheep and genetic material? What industry consultation processes are proposed to finalise the review of the policy?

—As all honourable senators will know, particularly those from rural areas of Australia, this is a sensitive issue for the Australian wool industry and has been for a long time. A number of key controls are currently in place under the federal government's merino export policy. Merino ram exports from Australia are restricted by a quota, and the export of ewes, embryos and ova is embargoed. The Department of Primary Industries and Energy has completed a detailed discussion paper on this policy, based on extensive analysis of the potential impact on the industry of any change in that policy. Copies of this discussion paper will be available from my department later this afternoon. The discussion paper recommends the complete removal of all controls on the export of merino sheep and merino genetic material from Australia.
—The horse has bolted.

—Senator Panizza, it is a discussion paper, and I invite you to let me or the department know, as I am sure you will, your views on the subject because I recognise the significance of this recommendation to the wool industry in Australia. Before I take a decision on this matter, I want to ensure that those potentially affected—including a lot of people outside the wool industry who have sensitivities about this matter—have an opportunity to comment on the discussion paper. These comments should be provided to the department by Friday, 22 April. I urge all people with an interest to respond.

PARA.TAB: The department will ensure that all individuals and groups who have provided submissions for the review will receive a copy of the discussion paper. The department will also undertake a structured consultation process with the relevant peak industry groups. In the past, the quota has been set in March. I do not intend to make a decision on this matter until I have made a thorough assessment of the views expressed by industry in response to the discussion paper. However, I can assure all interested parties that I will take a decision on this matter in plenty of time for the July auction sales.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. How far does the recent agreement between North Korea and the International Atomic Energy Agency on the implementation of nuclear safeguards inspection go towards satisfying international concerns about the DPRK's nuclear activities?

—A team of inspectors from the International Atomic Energy Agency, the IAEA, is scheduled to arrive in the North Korean capital of Pyongyang today to resume the agency's nuclear safeguards activities. This development follows months of difficult negotiations between the two parties on terms for the resumption of inspections. The inspections are designed to provide a basis for assurance that the DPRK's declared nuclear sites have not been used for weapons related activities since IAEA inspectors were last there conducting inspections—in August 1993.

PARA.TAB: Australia welcomes the DPRK's decision to cooperate with the International Atomic Energy Agency. We look to it now to ensure this and subsequent inspections proceed without hindrance. We await the report of IAEA inspectors with great interest. The inspection will take about two weeks, and further time will be required for the analysis of samples of nuclear material taken from DPRK sites.

A satisfactory outcome would be an important first step towards North Korea's full compliance with its safeguards obligations under the nuclear non-proliferation treaty. The DPRK's level of cooperation on the nuclear issue will be monitored closely by the IAEA board of governors, which is presently under Australian chairmanship. The commencement of the inspection had been delayed until the conclusion on 26 February of working level negotiations in New York between the DPRK and the United States about the timing and content of the third round of high level talks.

Completion of the initial resumed inspection will meet a key condition for those talks. North Korea has also agreed to resume dialogue with South Korea on an exchange of special envoys—the second condition for the talks with the United States. Another expected element is announcement of the suspension of the annual US-South Korean `Team Spirit' military exercise.

We hope that the US-DPRK high level talks will provide the basis for a long-term settlement of the nuclear issue which must, of course, include the DPRK's full compliance with its nuclear non-proliferation treaty obligations, involving in the longer term a resolution of the question still outstanding about North Korea's undeclared nuclear waste sites. The talks should also help to promote cooperative relations between the two Koreas and facilitate the DPRK's gradual and positive involvement in regional issues.

As Prime Minister Keating said in response to a question in the House of Representatives on 3 February, this whole matter of North Korea's nuclear status and activity is of the highest security significance to the region as a whole and indeed to Australia. We remain committed to dialogue and negotiation as the best way to resolve this issue, but we would also support stronger international action, including action by the Security Council, if the DPRK does prove unwilling to move towards full compliance with its NPT safeguards obligations.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel—that brilliant young minister, Senator Faulkner. I refer the minister to the success of Ryan Marine Products of Southport, Queensland, in once again being placed on the United States Defense Department's purchase list and to the new Samuels laboratory in Melbourne in its researching of measures to reduce the detectability of naval surface ships and submarines. I ask: can the minister inform the Senate on the potential for Ryan Marine and the new laboratory to put Australia to the fore in this vital field of defence research?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL; VETERANS' AFFAIRS; SPORT AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the magnificent government whip for his question! I acknowledge his ongoing interest in defence matters, particularly as they relate to the success of Queensland industry. Specifications for naval propellers typically require tolerances more demanding than for commercial standards in order to ensure high performance and lower noise and vibration.

PARA.TAB: In the early 1980s, the Department of Defence identified a need to improve the methods of propeller measurement during the production in Australia of replacement propellers for the Fremantle class patrol boat. This led to a search for a tolerance measuring system that would confirm that the propellers were within specification. Ryan Marine Products was identified as a potential supplier for a suitable system, and the department assisted the company in developing equipment to meet the navy's specific needs. A prop scan measuring system was supplied to SS Engineering in Perth with the support of the department. This was used for the successful completion of the contract for the manufacture of Fremantle propellers.

In addition to measurement during the manufacturing process, there is a need for measurement of propellers while ships are in service. A contract for the development of a ship afloat propeller measuring system was awarded to Ryan Marine Products under the defence industry development program. A trial on HMAS Geelong in August 1990 indicated the prototype system was suitable, and the equipment will be further developed for wider naval use. The department has provided assistance from the defence export program to Ryan Marine in overseas marketing, including the provision of staff to accompany Mr Ryan in demonstrating his measuring systems to customers in the US.

The ship-borne equipment will be loaned to Ryan Marine for demonstration to potential clients in the US and Canada, where there is also significant interest in this project. As a result, the equipment has, for the second year running, been approved for investigation by the United States navy, in the Pentagon's foreign comparative testing program. Ryan Marine Products should be heartily congratulated on this achievement. The range of propeller measuring systems developed by this Australian company is unique, and does have a significant worldwide marketing potential.

In relation to the second part of Senator Jones's question, which dealt with the Leonard Samuels laboratory for noise and vibration research, it is true that this laboratory will play a key role in the Defence, Science and Technology Organisation's undertaking of major projects in naval ship and submarine construction.

Located at DSTO's materials research laboratory in Melbourne, the new laboratory will help reduce the detectability of Royal Australian Navy ships and submarines, and therefore increase the safety of its personnel with its state-of-the-art experimental facilities.

The laboratory will also further enhance DSTO's ability to assist Australian industry, as well as defence, and continue as a significant contribution to large naval projects, such as the Collins class submarine, which are not only important to the navy but also to our national economy.

As the research and development arm of the Department of Defence, DSTO is giving a vital advantage to the defence organisation, as well as contributing to the development of a technologically competent and economically viable Australian manufacturing sector.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development. Media reports earlier this week outlined the case of a small Perth company linking with the Finnish mobile telecommunications specialist Nokia to develop state-of-the-art telecommunications base stations. What role did the government play in helping this small Australian company enter the global marketplace?

—The government has a partnerships for development program, which is part of our general information industry strategy. The purpose of this program is to target overseas companies which are going to sell more than $40 million worth of equipment in Australia in the telecommunications area, in software and in services, to either the Commonwealth government or the state and territory governments, and to then encourage those companies to partner with Australian companies so the Australian companies do a large proportion of their local work in manufacture and assembly. As well as that, they develop an export plan from Australia to overseas, particularly in our target markets.

PARA.TAB: After seven years they are required to have 70 per cent local value added content in their product. That is what the partnerships for development program does. We have an example now of the major Finnish communications giant Nokia, a foreign company, forming a partnership with ERG, a Perth company specialising in communications technology. They were joined under the partnerships for development program. It is worth noting that in 1985 ERG had 10 staff on its payroll; it now has 450 staff, the partnership deal having been done in 1992.

Before the Nokia partnership came along for ERG, ERG had annual sales worth $12 million. That was in 1991. This year its financial projections are that it will have sales of $110 million. That indicates that this program is working.

Under the agreement with Nokia, ERG is building the next generation of telecommunications base stations designed specifically for tropical environments. Australia is an ideal location for this sort of technology. ERG has commenced building earlier model base stations for Nokia and exported about 100 of these units to the Asia-Pacific region. The new units are designed to operate in extreme climatic and other conditions. The units are the first to integrate everything into a single cabinet, including power supply and electronic equipment. This cabinet allows the unit to handle extreme temperatures and also makes the unit vandal proof, thereby enabling it to be sited in remote areas.

The initial focus for export for this company will be Australia and New Zealand markets and there is scope, according to the management of the company, for exports in the Far East, in the Middle East and in the Mediterranean area. As well, the city of Fremantle figures in this export success story too. Fremantle has an important role in this because the Fremantle Port Authority has lent its lighthouse as a site for the proving and development of this technology. ERG has installed the global systems for mobile—GSM—on Fremantle Port Authority property.

The reason why it chose the Fremantle Port Authority is that it provides the sorts of conditions which can simulate conditions in the market targeted by this company. It is open to rugged wind conditions, it is open to extreme temperatures, and, of course, it is a salt infected site, an ideal location to prove up the hardiness and robustness of this Australian technology developed in association with a multinational giant. I know that Senator McKiernan, a Western Australian senator, is interested in that.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. Can the minister explain why the government stood by while Australian Stevedores, which is partly owned by the government, blatantly discriminated against union representatives by including a highly disproportionate number of them among the 55 employees who lost their jobs?

—I would hardly describe the actions of Minister Brereton as merely standing by. This dispute, as it evolved, required government intervention by the Minister for Industrial Relations. He did so. He brought the parties together. He appointed Mr Evans. He tried to resolve the matter and has pursued a resolution of the matter. At the moment, it is my understanding that the maritime union accepted the direction yesterday of the Industrial Relations Commission. Union members met today and accepted that. We are awaiting the response of Australian Stevedores, which will be announced in the commission today.

PARA.TAB: The fact that the government may part own—not majority own—any particular institution does not mean that it can necessarily direct that institution in industrial relations policy. Nor does it necessarily mean that the government is responsible for every act of some institution that it part owns; it is not responsible for its industrial relations policy. The government's responsibility was to see that this dispute, which clearly got out of hand at one stage, was brought back in and restricted to Sydney, which was achieved. Now that the matter is before the Industrial Relations Commission, we would like to see a resolution of the issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In view of the fact that International Labour Organisation Convention No. 98 in article 1 and the federal industrial relations legislation in section 334 incorporated provisions designed to prevent such blatant discrimination against union officials, will the minister advise the Senate whether a breach of either the Industrial Relations Act or the ILO convention took place? If the workers are not reinstated, as per the IRC recommendation, what action does the Australian government propose to take?

—I am not sure whether the premise on which the question has been asked is absolutely true. It is not for the government to make a judgment on those particular matters; it is for the Australian Industrial Relations Commission to make those judgments. We can hardly set the rules and umpire everything. That is why we established an independent body to reflect the legislation and to eventually judge what is contained in international conventions. It is for that body to make that judgment. It is open and always possible for us, in certain circumstances where we become concerned about a matter, to intervene and put a point of view.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Trade. This morning's Australian Financial Review reported on a forthcoming world infrastructure forum in Jakarta and identified the trade and economic opportunities arising from Asia's enormous infrastructure needs in the coming decade. For example, China's needs alone total an estimated $400 billion and Korea's about $200 billion. In this context, what is Australia doing to improve the competitiveness of Australian companies bidding for international infrastructure contracts?

—I am very glad that at least honourable senators on this side are concerned about some issues that mean jobs for Australians. In the reports in the Australian Financial Review and in the evidence available from other reports concerning airport capacity in the region and so on, it is made clear that there are going to be enormous infrastructure needs in this region. One of the risks is that the total of those infrastructure needs is so great—in the trillions of dollars in some analyses—that people get mesmerised and smaller companies think that this is an operation of such a scale that there is no role for them in it. It is important that we recognise that this is not the case.

PARA.TAB: There is already active encouragement for Australian construction companies to form export consortia to win contracts. They have been quite successful, including about a billion dollars worth of projects in the new Hong Kong airport. Austrade in particular works very closely with a construction industry export group and has had some notable successes in facilitating successful Australian tenders, for example in China. I was discussing yesterday with the relevant Austrade representative the success of an Australian company in the sale of mounted cranes to New Zealand railways.

An enormous amount of work has also been done by the Australian government to facilitate Australian participation in World Bank and Asian Development Bank projects and through AIDAB-funded projects such as the extremely successful Mekong Friendship Bridge. This provides a showcase for our capabilities. My colleague and predecessor Senator Cook was involved in a number of initiatives to give high-level promotion to the Australian construction industry, in particular a business mission to China which led to a substantial amount of interest in projects for which follow-up work is now under way. Last year's National Trade and Investment Outlook Conference had a focus on the construction industry as will this year's conference. In a variety of other places, including Indonesia, there are major Australian initiatives promoting Australian trade and giving emphasis to the potential for the generation of Australian wealth and jobs. The construction industry remains important in that.

Also, through the Uruguay Round we did achieve some valuable commitments—for example, from most of the ASEAN countries—providing legally binding guarantees on market access for Australian construction contractors. I reiterate that there is enormous potential here from which Australia is well placed to benefit. It is very big, but it is not too big for Australian industry to succeed. We are working to help Australian industry succeed in getting a significant proportion of this work because, unlike those who are obsessed with 1989 issues, we are concerned with 1994-95 opportunities and jobs for Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Science and Small Business. I understand that the minister has released an exposure draft of the proposed trademarks legislation. Can the minister explain why he has taken the relatively unusual step of inviting comment on this legislation before its introduction into the parliament? Also, why has it taken so long for this draft to be prepared? How long is the proposed exposure period to be?

—I think we should recognise this as another major step in the government's policy of recognising the value of intellectual property and the role it will play in our becoming an internationally competitive economy because trademarks are a very important part of that. The proposed trademarks bill is an outcome of a working party which reviewed the legislation. The working party was made up of nominees from the Institute of Patent Attorneys of Australia, the Law Council of Australia and the Trade Marks Office. While this legislation represents a broad range of opinion, the government believes that it is important legislation, that it has great consumer and industry interest, and that the draft bill should be made available to the public for a six-month period before the government makes a final decision on the content of the bill.

PARA.TAB: This is the first time in 35 years that the Trade Marks Act has been amended. I point out that in 1955, when the then Attorney-General, Senator Spicer, introduced the Trade Marks Act, he said that it would need to be reviewed periodically. I must say, 35 years was probably longer than Senator Spicer had anticipated.

The primary object of the bill is to protect consumers so that they know what they are getting and what to ask for, and to protect traders and the ownership value of the trademark. The thrust of the bill is also to ensure that we are able to protect Australian trademarks at the international level and make our position internationally appropriate. As I said before, that is a major factor in Australia becoming, as it should become, an internationally competitive economy.

The bill keeps pace with the provisions of changing methods of business, and I am pleased to say in particular that the draft incorporates the plain English drafting style which I think all members in the Senate would welcome. I certainly will welcome it, and believe consumers and the industry will welcome the bill being in the plain English drafting style.

I urge senators and all other members of parliament to encourage those people and industry groups in the community interested in this bill, and there are many, to have a look at the bill over the next six months and make submissions. From that, the government will be able to proceed with a bill clearly of advantage to the community and Australia, and particularly Australia's international trading environment.

—I address my question to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and refer the minister to recent media reports that the European Union is reviewing its visa arrangements for overseas visitors. Will Australians need visas to visit Europe from 1996? Is this related to the fact that the Australian visa system is seen as cumbersome for European tourists?

—I thank Senator Reynolds for a timely question referring to recent reports. The ABC program AM ran a report out of Europe last week. The issue was also discussed last week by officials of the European Union and officers of my department. The situation is not as clear as given in the ABC report. Unfortunately it was, once again, sensationalist and wrong. The evidence from the European Commission is that the situation here is evolving. The list produced by the commissioner, although admitting there are some problems with it, is one that he expects will change. It has run into opposition from, for instance, Great Britain, as the list of those who will require visas includes most of the Commonwealth countries.

PARA.TAB: The officials meeting held in Canberra last week discussed what the European Commission is doing on the convention on external territories and how the common list for the European Union will affect Australia. The position of Australia is that we should be excluded from that list of countries whose residents have to produce visas to enter Europe.

One main reason for our position is that, despite periodic bleatings from members of our community, there has been a bipartisan acceptance of the fact that we need to have visas issued offshore. We have a system in Australia which is working quite well and quite effectively, and we are building on it. Officers from my department are able to explain to European officials that work is already under way for the introduction of a facilitation scheme for travel into Australia. For instance, on 22 June 1993 I wrote to various ministers advising them that development work had begun on a new electronic visa issue system which was designed to simplify entry into Australia from our most important tourism markets in Asia, North America and Europe.

The new system has the objective of extending delivery systems in high volume, low risk tourist markets and providing ready access to almost all travellers from participating countries. We expect it will be put in place over the next two years. It will be virtually invisible to tourists. No written application will be required and no visa will be placed in the passbook. The application to enter Australia will be made by presenting a passport to an authorised agent who will seek the authorisation to travel electronically, in much the same way as the agent presently makes airline accommodation bookings. The entry authority will be electronically provided to the agent, and the details will be presented in the traveller's itinerary.

These arrangements will be extended to nationals of countries with a specific tourist profile. The sorts of criteria that we are looking at include volume of tourism, a low overstay rate, and machine-readable passports to manage the risk of different tourist source markets.

This new scheme is to build on a system which already demands only some 45 seconds per passenger when that passenger comes into Australia. The reaction so far within Australia from governments, industry and travel information specialists has been favourable. We do not see any real impediment to the introduction of such a system and we will be proceeding with plans to do so. In the meantime we will continue holding discussions with EC countries so that they may better appreciate the situation in Australia.
