TALK.START.PARA: —Last evening at 7.20 we had a new President in the chair and new standing orders of this Senate. I noted that the new President very zealously endeavoured on that occasion to meet the requirements, even though I was desperately trying to indicate to him that I had approximately half a minute to a minute to finish my particular speech in this second reading debate. I will therefore have to reiterate a little of those comments and also conclude the remaining part of that speech.

PARA.TAB: In considering the agricultural and veterinary chemicals legislation that is before us, it was necessary to canvass a whole range of matters that address this particular issue. I had, in my main speech, endeavoured to cover those points that were so necessary. I had reached the point of referring to the necessity for ongoing study and research in the chemical-veterinary area, and pointed out that a wise and sensible use of chemicals has an important role in maintaining agricultural production and, at the same time, helping maintain the quality and diversity of our soils.

Australian agriculture is an enormous employer of technology and modern methods. For example, an Australian company is seeking permission to run field trials of cotton plants which have been genetically engineered to improve their resistance to caterpillars and, paradoxically, the herbicide roundup. The company is confident that if the trials are successful and the plants are released commercially the chemicals that are used on Australia's very substantial cotton crop could be reduced. Such advantages are not limited to broadacre farming.

The sheep industry is awaiting the commercial availability of transgenic sheep, which are resistant to the sheep blow-fly—a pest responsible for significant losses of wool production in this country. As a community we are right to carefully monitor the nature and use of chemicals in agriculture but should not be blinded to the enormous benefits to farmers and mankind. They already help our rural sector to do more than just feed Australia. They allow that sector to feed and clothe some 55 million people globally, bring in billions of dollars of export every year and employ hundreds and thousands of Australians not directly involved in primary production in our biggest manufacturing sector, the food processing sector.

I briefly note the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs handed down last week, and to which Senator Sherry made a brief government statement last night. The government basically accepted the thrust of that report. The committee recommended in its comments on this particular package of bills that the legislation be reviewed after 18 to 20 months of operation. I am pleased to note that the government accepted that recommendation. The review should address such issues as public access to information; cost recovery, including community service obligations; and third party appeals and control of use after sale. I also indicate the federal Liberal and National parties agree with these findings and support this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats are gravely concerned about this package of bills. As Senator Tambling has told us, it is an historic package. Each bill in its own right has an historic effect. But in the view of the Democrats these bills fail to meet the standards and procedures required by new national uniform registration systems for the nation's chemicals. I am disappointed to say that the bills are inadequate. But I am not seeking the immediate banning or abolition of all manufactured chemicals and compounds in use for agricultural and veterinary purposes. I again place on record my disquiet as to the way that we, as a society, have built a reliance upon using chemicals, not only in agriculture, but in our kids' classrooms, our homes and workplaces, with almost total disregard for the consequences in terms of health, economics and eventually the employment and structure of our nation. If that seems to be going a little too far, we should think very carefully about the way chemicals have inveigled their way into our society.

PARA.TAB: As a nation we have become addicted to the idea that we must continue to be throwing more and more poisons at our food in ever increasing quantities in order to feed ourselves and pay for our insatiable thirst for importing products we do not need or could grow and manufacture quite well ourselves. Over time we have been lulled into a false sense of acceptance towards the ever expanding use and reliance on chemicals by industry and government.

The newsletter Farm Chemicals Today provides us with a good example of my point. It is basically a propaganda sheet from the chemical industry designed to calm people's growing fears about chemical use. A recent edition, for example, has Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . ranked amongst the world's safest food countries.

It is all very well, but it is not good enough. This is reinforced by the government departments and agencies now busily trying to foster the image of clean, green, produce. We have to be very careful about the superficial use of such words and look behind exactly what we mean when such statements are thrown about.

PARA.TAB: That is only one side of the story. We do not need more and more chemicals; we do need to be using fewer and fewer chemicals. Despite clear warnings, more pesticides are being used in more countries on more crops causing more damage today than ever before. Global pesticide sales have, reportedly, increased a huge 31 times since 1960. From cradle to grave, from production and use to storage and disposal, pesticides pose increasing threats to human life and the environment which sustains us.

It has been suggested that damages from pesticide use alone costs more than $100 billion worldwide yearly. This has to be contrasted with the claimed beneficial use of chemicals in agriculture. These costs are hard to enumerate and justify in some ways. It is because as a society we have not really undertaken a cost-benefit study into the real cost of using them and the real benefits. One thing we do know is that part of the cost is the ever increasing regulatory and control mechanisms. This package of bills introduces yet another aspect.

Already there are monitoring authorities and tools such as the National Food Authority, residue surveys, market basket surveys and so on, which have already been put in place to protect ourselves and our children. These costs eventually arrive at the consumer's wallet. There is no other place that they can be met from. Honourable senators will recall that over the past year, since I related the incident of schoolchildren in Tasmania being sprayed with chemicals, I have brought a continuing catalogue of disasters resulting from chemical use or abuse. I am pleased to say that the efforts I have made there have encouraged more and more people to speak out against this modern threat to our existence.

A story a couple of months ago concerned a man around 30 years of age who accidentally drank endosulsan and as a consequence is now dead. What kind of regime do we have to put in place that can register such stuff for public use?

TALK.START.PARA: —I know someone who drank 2,4,5 T and he is still alive!

—Senator Brownhill, I know, knows better than to think that such an interjection about someone who drank some 2,4,5 T and is still alive is a worthwhile contribution to the debate. The fact is we have registered such materials for public use, when there is no known antidote for some of them. The opportunity for misuse is easily taken. At the moment we seem to be more concerned about building safety fences around backyard swimming pools, which communities around Australia are enraged about; we have been subjected to decades of discussion and great wringing of hands to ensure that the right regime is brought into place. But in dealing daily with potentially fatal chemical compounds we do not seem to be getting quite so worried about it in a regulatory sense.

PARA.TAB: Some honourable senators will be aware of the furore created by the Tasmanian Forestry Commission's decision to aerially spray atrazine around young plantation pine trees at Lorinna, northern Tasmania, to retard weed growth. In answer to a question on notice, Senator Richardson has informed me that atrazine is no longer approved for use—presumably meaning banned—in Sweden due to concerns over possible water contamination. He also maintains that atrazine does not pose a health risk when used for the same purpose in Tasmania. There is something about the antipodean traversing across the equator, something like the Norwegian liquor that we saw where some magical effect took place when it went over the equator. I am sure that does not happen to atrazine. If it is not safe in Sweden, it is not safe in Tasmania.

The government's escape hatch is the ubiquitous maximum residue level circus, the MRL, which is the level of chemical residue expected to occur in foods when a chemical is used as recommended but has nothing to do with the contamination of a town's water supply. Why do we have a system that has to wait for an outbreak of atrazine poisoning to be traced back to the spraying at Lorinna in the backblocks of Tasmania before we take the hazards of chemical use more seriously? Why is that? Why do we not recognise it? Is it because the words are so complicated? Is it because the effects are so complicated? Is it because it is so easy to cover up misuse? I do not know. I think those questions need to be answered.

Not long ago the Victorian government was obliged to pay compensation to farmers who used dieldrin in the recommended way. As honourable senators will know, the dieldrin beef contamination scandal was the catalyst for the establishment of the Senate Select Committee on Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals which reported in July 1990. I remind honourable senators that that committee was established by the Democrats and included Senator Coulter, who performed a very valuable task in ensuring that the committee followed the matter through and reported to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was deputy chairman of that.

—The deputy chairman, Senator Brownhill, also played a very valuable part. The committee was a vehicle for bringing to the Senate's attention a number of issues which should be addressed in this legislation. We know, not only from the work of that committee but also from public information, that the organochlorine DDT is used for termite control in Queensland even though its use has been prohibited there since 1987. Residues of DDT were recently discovered in beef carcasses meant for export to Japan. Apparently, some of the contaminated meat came from a feedlot on a site that some time ago was a dip site; other meat came from sites that were previously sugarcane fields.

PARA.TAB: One of the many questions that arise from this instance is: how many contaminations are waiting to happen throughout Australia? We do not know exactly where these sites are. People who are preparing produce for sale overseas are sometimes ignorant of what their farming property was used for previously. This ought to be of concern when we register chemicals but I am not convinced that this legislative package will resolve the problem. There have been numerous reports and examples of contamination of food and severe toxic effects of chemical applications on populations. Reports are now emerging of toxic effects of chemical usage in schools and industries. Honourable senators will recall that I recounted the episode of the Dalton Special School in Hobart. It is no longer a school but we still do not know the chemical application that caused the problem at that site.

Earlier in this Senate session I told the story of one Pat Snowdon, the victim of chemical poisoning from her previous occupation as a cleaner using the glycol ether, ethylene glycol mono-butyl ether. Glycol ethers have been linked with miscarriages, reproductive damage, central nervous system damage and adverse effects on liver and kidneys. Glycol ethers, at this very moment, are being used to clean schools and many other public buildings. Why do we continue to allow that use? I do not know, and I do not think this legislative package is going to solve that problem either. Although people have been calling for a review of that chemical for many years, we still have an allowable exposure concentration well above allowable levels in the United States. There, new rules have recently been proposed for the reclassification of glycol ethers by the Environment Protection Agency. It concluded:

SPEECH.PARA: Based on current data, the EPA is not able to establish molecular size or weight above which there are no concerns for adverse effects on human health.

In other words, it could not determine a minimum. I could go on in this vein for days—I am sure honourable senators would be very excited about the content of my speech—but I do not need to do that to demonstrate that we do have a very large problem that requires attention. To be fair, these bills hint at recognising the problem. My disappointment is not so much with their content nor even their direction, but with the fact that, although they address the problem, they do not solve it, and that is not just my opinion.

PARA.TAB: The Senate committee which inquired into the bills heard genuine concerns about them. The chairman of the national registration authority endorsed some of those concerns and had serious concerns of his own. I propose to move a second reading amendment which expresses his concerns. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At the end of motion, add:

",but the Senate calls on the Government to make provision for funds to be made available for the National Registration Authority for Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals, to enable it to perform community service obligations essential to the evaluation and control of agricultural and veterinary chemical products".

I find it strange that the chairman of the NRA can express the concern that there is no provision in this bill for funding to meet community service obligations, yet it is in no way addressed in this package. The committee understood his concern and recommended that it be part of the review in several months time. We have talked about the decades it has taken to reach this point—the negotiations, the exposure draft, the discussions that took place with state governments and the preamble to this bill. If we did not address a basic concern of the chairman of the NRA, what was the purpose of putting together such a package?

PARA.TAB: Other concerns were picked up by the committee and acknowledged by the minister, and I note the promise of a review of the legislation in 18 months time. I support that recommendation. I consider it a reasonably cheap promise for him to make—a concession that the government was able to make rather painlessly in this position. In the meantime, whether or not that is picked up in the review process, I will ensure that the operations of the authority are closely monitored. It is not just me doing this, but the people who have been expressing concerns for decades about how Australia has been sucked along this path of the use and misuse of chemicals. I will ensure that the results of that monitoring are put on the public record for its ongoing monitoring and as a starting point of the promised review.

That is really second best. This legislation had a chance to be based on a foundation of proper ecologically sustainable development principles, but they are not even spelt out properly in the bill. The bills should provide for the implementation of those principles, not just superficially mentioning them. I will be providing a simple amendment that attempts to give recognition to the principle that we should be precautionary in our acceptance of new chemicals. If we must unleash more and more of these products into our environment, we must be sure there will be no adverse effects; it cannot be any other way. We should be precautionary in our introduction.

The bills provide for a public record to be kept. This could be properly databased and contain all the relevant information on products and their constituents. It might yet turn out to be so. It could also be used to maintain incident and usage information. That usage information could detail the history and geography of usage and provide a national accessible poisons schedule in a user friendly format. This is one aspect of the legislation I will want very carefully watched. I believe that the bills fail to provide a proper monitoring capacity. So far, the argument about control of use has been used as an excuse for the failure to ensure that the NRA is required to monitor the effects of the chemicals it registers.

The committee was presented with a feasible system of feedback and proper monitoring. I will be moving an amendment that makes it clear that the NRA should be seeking feedback from the public about the effects of chemicals, consistent with the conclusions of the 1990 Senate select committee findings. It is nonsense to suggest that it is sufficient to register chemicals and not be required to have some responsibility for the effects of the use of the chemicals. A complete lack of systematic monitoring of the levels or effects of agricultural chemicals was lamented by a number of the bodies that presented submissions to the Senate select committee on agriculture, including the Bureau of Rural Resources, the Australian Conservation Foundation and the Victorian government.

Much has been said about openness and transparency. Indeed, I think the chairman of the NRA did acknowledge the cynicism with which this legislation is viewed by many people. Such cynicism, it is said, derives from past practices and, to his credit, the chairman indicated that it is the NRA's intention to do better, to be more open. I remain to be convinced.

I note the intention to address the issues of public access to information and the responses about the concerns over the commercial-in-confidence issue. For the moment, I will be content with an amendment that assists making the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette the vehicle for providing public notification of government activity. If we are serious about the public's right to know, this amendment will receive bipartisan support. It only requires that it be published in daily newspapers as well.

The committee did pick up on the concern about third parties. However, restricting applications for variations of approvals for registration to narrowly defined applicants unnecessarily excludes the public from this process. I will be moving an amendment that is designed to overcome that problem. My view of this legislation is that it really ought to be withdrawn and redrafted to take account of the concerns expressed last week at the public hearing. I cannot understand why, after so many years, there are still so many uncertainties and concerns about this package.

At the hearing we heard a submission that called for the board to include the appointment of an additional director who has experience in ecology and environmental protection. I moved such an amendment when the board was originally established in 1992. It was opposed. Yet at the hearing we heard again the argument that the current arrangements provide for environmental expertise. If that were really the case then the bills would be different, they would look different and they would contain the amendments I have already alluded to which were first moved in December 1992. The legislation is certainly inadequate and it cannot receive my support without substantial amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —This package of seven agricultural and veterinary chemicals bills has been a number of years in development. The Senate established in November 1988 the Select Committee on Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals in Australia. I was deputy chairman at that stage and you, Mr Acting Deputy President Colston, were the chairman—it is good to see you sitting in the chair while these bills are being debated.

PARA.TAB: The committee was charged with examining: the adequacy of arrangements under the existing legislation relating to agricultural and veterinary chemicals for administration and coordination systems for agricultural and veterinary chemicals; the efficiency of chemical, non-chemical and integrated management systems; and the economic, social and environmental impact of those chemicals on Australia. At the time of the inquiry there was much concern about the indiscriminate use of chemicals in Australia, the lack of information about the toxicity of chemicals, and the inconsistency of registration of chemicals—many of the things about which Senator Bell has just been talking.

It was thought the committee would be unable to bring down a consensus report because of the differing political views of the members of the committee. History will record that, in fact, the committee's report was unanimous. The committee made 45 recommendations relating to improved mechanisms for registration and research funding for an industry that was not well regulated, not cohesive and in need of improvement.

The select committee report was a blueprint for the management of farm chemicals and agricultural products. And for reasons known best only to the department of primary industries and to the government, the government response to the report took two years to formulate. The agricultural and veterinary chemicals committee brought down its report four years ago and we are at last seeing the legislative processes suggested in that report. Senator Tambling said in leading this debate for the opposition that we welcome the bills that have been introduced.

The package of seven bills will, in essence, provide a uniform, transparent, one-stop-shop national system of clearance and registration in accordance with the original committee's recommendations. It provides the National Registration Authority, which has been developed since 1992, with the legislative powers to function; amends existing legislation; and introduces a levy on agricultural and veterinary products manufactured in Australia and a levy on those imported into Australia.

While I support the thrust of the legislation, it is not perfect. It does not cover as many issues as it ought to. The government needs to examine the question of chemicals a lot more thoroughly, most particularly from the user point of view. It should also be examining ways of achieving better control from the point of sale. The Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs, which looked at these bills, made this pretty clear in its recent report. That area remains untidy and open to difficulties and needs to be thoroughly considered.

However, my view is that something is better than nothing. I am hopeful that the National Registration Authority, having been given some legislative teeth, will start to work. That is also the view of the Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs to which this legislation was referred. As it happens, I now happen to be the deputy chairman of that committee. The secretary of the Select Committee on Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals in Australia is now the secretary of the Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs. So it is very much a case of revisiting a lot of the arguments. In looking at the legislation in the last few weeks, we have actually received quite a depth of information about agricultural and veterinary chemicals.

The rural and regional affairs committee report tabled last week supports the thrust of the legislation, with the reservations that I have just mentioned. Interestingly, the witnesses who appeared before the committee this year expressed similar views to those expressed many years ago to the select committee. The National Farmers Federation welcomed the legislation, saying the consultative process to develop the legislation was `very thorough'. The NFF said that it was highly supportive of the legislation because:

SPEECH.PARA: It contains much of the tried and proven elements of the existing registration process while adding essential new features, including proprietary rights to registration data and provision for registration of minor uses.
The federation suggested that the legislation provided:

A much more transparent and open registration process that will provide greater public certainty that concerns about health and environmental safety have been thoroughly considered . . . The bills strike a reasonable balance between the transparency of the process, availability of information to the public and the need to protect costly and commercially valuable information that is submitted as part of the registration process.

I note that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Senator Sherry, said yesterday that the government will ensure that the main interest groups are kept informed of relevant agricultural and veterinary chemical matters; and that a direct mailing list is to be developed so that these groups will be advised by a consolidated notice from the NRA and, consequently, they will not need to hunt through daily newspapers looking for notices. People in the community like Senator Bell, who has been making points in this place, will have a much better expression of views of what is happening with that process.

PARA.TAB: Associations like the Australian Veterinary Association Ltd also support the legislation; but the AVA expressed concern about the after sale use. I might add that the legislation did not cover control of after sale use because the federal government, in consultation with the states, had agreed that it should remain with state governments to administer the control. Maybe we should be working with the state governments to see whether they can agree to change that a little bit. The AVA submission states:

SPEECH.PARA: To illustrate the serious difficulties that can arise, in most States (but not all) it is not an offence to use registered products at higher dose rates than recommended on the label or in species other than those listed on the label, eg. products for sheep can be used legally in pigs. Furthermore, some States have different controls on veterinary medicines and pesticides for external use on animals.
Obviously, if we could get the states all agreeing to other things, we would actually get a much better, friendlier use of chemicals in Australia.

PARA.TAB: The same concerns were raised by the Veterinary Manufacturers and Distributors Association. It made particularly valid points in suggesting that:

SPEECH.PARA: VMDA . . . has been of the opinion that the control of use should be in Canberra and that it should be a Commonwealth function . . . State lines on a map are completely irrelevant as far as the use of remedies, applications, herbicides and pesticides are concerned.

Concerns were expressed as to the cost recovery mechanisms proposed under the legislation, and manufacturers suggested that the cost of chemical registrations could conceivably rise 250 per cent. However, they acknowledge the importance of such procedures.

PARA.TAB: On the matter of cost recovery, I draw to the attention of the Senate that in 1992 there was to be a 50 per cent cost recovery, increasing to 67 per cent in 1993-94, and then reaching 100 per cent in 1995-96.

Other criticisms about the legislation came from groups such as the public interest advocacy centre, and environment groups such as the Australian Conservation Foundation, who said that there had been a lack of public consultation, and that they had received the legislation—a package of some several hundred pages—only in October last year.

The PIAC suggested a number of amendments to the committee, including changes to the composition of the NRA board. However the chairman of the National Registration Authority, Professor Ben Selinger, told the committee that acceptance of the amendments would require negotiations to be reopened with the states, and the whole process would be delayed. That sums up the dilemma for the committee in proposing any amendments to the Senate.

The committee believed that the legislation should be implemented without delay, but it also believed that it should also be reviewed. We are recommending that the agricultural and veterinary chemicals legislation should be reviewed after 18 to 20 months of operation, which gives us a chance to find out any teething problems that may be attached to it. However, I do not think there will be any problems. I think the NRA will do a good job with the legislation. We want to make sure that there has been public access to information, as was intended, and that there has been the cost recovery, which I have just mentioned, including community service obligations, third party appeals, and the control of use after sale.

We asked for a commitment on that from the minister, and he gave us that commitment yesterday through the parliamentary secretary, when he said that he was happy to agree that the agricultural and veterinary chemicals legislation be reviewed after 18 to 20 months. I think that is excellent because it does not do any harm to look at some of the legislation that goes through this place to see whether it is operating in the way in which it was meant to operate.

As honourable senators know, Senator Bell issued a dissenting report to the committee's majority report. I think it is regrettable that the senator felt there was need to do that, because I am quite confident that the proposed review will encompass many of the matters he raises while, at the same time, giving the legislation an opportunity to start working. Senator Bell said that 18 months would be too long to wait but, in fairness, the NRA needs to be given time to operate, and having waited years to get the legislation in place, I do not think it is unreasonable to wait a further 18 months to see whether what is in place is functioning adequately.

As to the suggestion that the NRA board be changed to include an environmentalist, I have no objection per se to an environmentalist being on the board. But where do we draw the line? Should we not have a vet, a doctor, a horticulturist? On the other hand, why do we have a television personality on it? The fact is, for whatever reason, that is the composition of the board. At the end of the board's term there will be an opportunity to change the membership if it is deemed appropriate to do so at that time.

No legislation is ever perfect. In recent years the legislation emanating from this government has been less than perfect. But that aside, the legislation before us now here today is long overdue by any judgment. It is important that we get a system in place, even if over time it is proven to be imperfect.

There needs to be a great deal more emphasis on farm safety aspects of chemical use. I use this opportunity to applaud the work of the farm safe groups around New South Wales in highlighting the safe use of chemicals.

Over the years I have used many chemicals. I see Senator Panizza here, and I know that in Western Australia farmers use chemicals to make sure that they protect their land by not tilling it too hard with machines. There is a need for more research into the effects of chemicals, and encouragement given to less toxic alternatives. We need to consider all the other methods of control of weeds and insects, such as biological controls.

There needs to be serious consideration given to what realistically ought to be the responsibility of the Commonwealth, given that state boundaries are, with one exception, merely a geographical note on a map. Despite its shortcomings, I believe this legislation is a move in the right direction. I welcome the passage of it, and I support the remarks that Senator Tambling made earlier in this debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak only for a brief time, but I want to raise a few points which I think are quite important, and some of which actually bear on legislation which, in some ways, parallels this legislation. As Senator Brownhill and others have already said, this package of bills marks a significant change in the way in which we register and regulate agricultural chemicals. It is certainly a move in the right direction in the sense that hitherto, while we have had an advisory system at the national level, the registration and regulation of these agents has been in the hands of the states, and there has been a variability between the states. That has been quite unsatisfactory, both with respect to the manufacturers, the marketers, the suppliers of these chemicals, and also the users. It was an unnecessarily cumbersome and rather expensive system.

PARA.TAB: So it is certainly heartening to see that we are at last adopting a uniform system. But therein lies a very considerable danger. I think we will see an example of this when we deal with the Democrat amendments. The danger is that, rather than adopting a national system at the national level, what we have chosen to do is to go through a federalist-type system in which we need the cooperation and the agreement of the various states.

What that has meant—and this is where I draw attention to other legislation of a similar type—and what it means in this case is that essentially it bypasses the democratic process because, as we will be told by the minister, it will be impossible for this chamber to amend this legislation. If we changed one comma or one full stop, such changes would also have to be adopted by the states.

The same argument will be used if, say, Democrats in South Australia or New South Wales attempt to move any amendments to complimentary legislation that is put forward at state level. They will be told that this legislation cannot be touched because there is an agreement between the Commonwealth and the states.

We saw that just the other week with the offshore minerals legislation. Again, when an attempt was made by the Democrats to pass very desirable legislation to prevent mining in national parks, the argument was again used that we could not interfere with that legislation because it was a model which was being presented to us; it had come forward after long negotiation between the Commonwealth and the states, and it could not be touched.

I signal to other senators that this is a very dangerous road, because it means that nowhere in the open, accountable system are these types of bills properly being dealt with by the parliament. We are just being asked to rubber-stamp what essentially has been agreed between bureaucrats behind closed doors over some period of time.

Not only does it relate to federalism but also it relates to international agreements. Honourable senators will recall that on several occasions, when dealing with legislation which is designed to give effect to an international agreement that Australia has entered into, exactly the same thing has happened. We have been told that we cannot interfere with this because this legislation is the result of an international agreement and we cannot change one comma or one full stop without in some way infringing the agreements that have been entered into.

I begin by raising that as a word of warning. We seem to be getting quite a bit of this type of legislation through at the present time. I find it quite unsatisfactory, and this package of bills is simply one example of the way in which this federalism is actually bypassing the whole open, accountable, democratic, political process.

TALK.START.PARA: —You didn't say that when the Mabo debate was on.

—Senator Panizza might well draw attention to Mabo but at least in the case of Mabo the federal government was dealing with legislation which will be imposed across the whole state. There was a very lively, democratic and open debate in this chamber which dealt with it. Had we been dealing with Mabo by way of a federalist type approach there would have been no opportunity for amendment or change whatsoever. I think Senator Panizza for one might have been less happy with that than what actually happened.

PARA.TAB: Ever since the Second World War there has been a growing concern about the dangers associated with the use of agricultural chemicals. Many of us will recall that just before and during the war the chemical industry really got into its stride with the development of a whole range of chemicals which were thought to be extremely good at the time because they were very persistent chemicals and seemed to have very low human toxicity. Because of their persistence it was thought that many of our problems with agricultural pests would be solved once and for all.

Early on there was no recognition of the twin problems: emerging resistance to those pesticides—there was often a concentration up food chains which resulted in predator animals at the top being far more affected by these pesticides than the pest which, by this time, had become resistant—and chemical persistence and long-term toxicity for humans, particularly genetic toxicity in relation to birth defects and cancer.

Rachel Carson, in Silent Spring—published, I think, in 1963—very dramatically drew attention to what had happened with the use of some of those organochlorine pesticides. Since then the list of agents which were formerly thought to be safe and which have since been discovered to have adverse side effects, either to the environment or to human health, has become longer and longer. It is that assumption of safety—more recently disabused by information about adverse effects—that sets the background against which we need to consider this type of legislation, the problems in relation to the continued use of these substances and also the development of alternatives.

I would like to mention briefly the research which would lead to the development of biological controls, because Senator Brownhill mentioned that in his closing remarks. Over recent years, this government has required the CSIRO and other organisations to obtain a substantial portion of their funding for research from private sources. Thirty per cent is the proportion to which CSIRO is supposed to adhere. In the area of agricultural chemicals, the development of biological controls is inimical to the interests of the chemical companies and therefore is not likely to be funded by chemical companies. CSIRO and other organisations are being pressured to bend their research to those areas of research which will attract commercial funding. The very research which is likely to get us out of our bind with agricultural chemicals—to reduce our use of agricultural chemicals—is therefore likely to be done less and less in Australia, given the pressure under which research institutes are being put.

One could mention, for instance, Senator Bell's home state of Tasmania where the department of agriculture has been working for some 15 years on biological control of a weed pest. That type of research is not going to attract commercial interest because, firstly, the time scale of the research is too long to be particularly profitable, and secondly, once the biological control is released it is no longer profitable to the company unless the organisation is able to build in some genetic control mechanism, which increasingly they are doing. That makes farmers and others subject in perpetuity to the control of the chemical companies and that, in itself, poses a very considerable danger. The direction this government has taken is therefore likely to further damage the research work which will lead to alternatives to chemicals.

I would like to pick up a couple of other points, one being the question of having an expert on the board, which was mentioned by Senator Bell and Senator Brownhill. We have seen the argument used repeatedly—it has been used by the NRA and by others in this particular case—that if there is a requirement for a person with a particular expertise, say, in the impact of particular classes of chemicals on natural environments and the organisms in natural environments, they can be called in. That really begs the question: how will the board know when to call that expert opinion in if it does not have that expertise already among its members? Repeatedly, we have seen that committees constructed like this one have failed to bring in the expert advice they need, not because they are in any way perverse, but simply because they are ignorant of the information that may be available to them.

The notion of having an expert on the environmental impact of agricultural chemicals on the board is an extremely good one. I do not think the argument of where do we stop, do we bring in a doctor, do we bring in this or that, is really to the point. The point is that these are chemicals which are being widely distributed into the environment. Repeatedly in the past we have seen adverse effects on a range of animals and plants in the environment—effects which are totally unexpected—often not showing up for some years afterwards. Because of that, this is the sort of expert who should really be on this board.

I am rather surprised by the concern over confidentiality. Most, if not all, of the agents used as agricultural chemicals in the commercial area are subject to patents. It seems to me that the possibility of anybody else manufacturing or selling any of these agents in competition with the larger suppliers is very remote.

The importance of openness of information lies in the fact that the public, including many of the doctors and others who would be asked to give advice to the public on the risks associated with agricultural chemicals, will have available to them predominantly the information which is provided by the chemical company. In the past we have seen numerous examples of chemical and drug companies filtering the information that goes to the public so that the good information—the advantages and benefits that flow from the use of the chemical—are given to the public, while the dangers—the risks and hazards associated with the use of the chemical—are not readily available or are put in very small type on the labels and are not generally accessible.

More than that, if, say, a farmer becomes concerned about a particular chemical which he or she is using, it is absolutely necessary that that person be able to get access to all the information on that particular agent. That person should be able to go to an independent expert and say, `Look, I am handling this particular material. What do you think?'. In particular, that person should be able to take it to somebody who has expressed concern about that chemical—somebody who is likely to give a view rather different from the view given by the chemical company.

It is for that reason, it is not good enough, as has been argued in some of the defences before us, that doctors and others can get access to that information only when a poisoning has occurred. It is important that everyone using chemicals has access to information when they are using or even thinking about using the chemicals and can go to an independent expert and get advice as to the risks associated with those chemicals. Again, I am very concerned about the aspect of commercial in-confidence as dealt with in this legislation.

In conclusion, one must remember that when one is dealing with these agricultural chemical companies, one is dealing with super giants. These are massive companies with billions of dollars of investment and financial, economic and legal power behind them. Some of them are extremely litigious and will very quickly make legal challenges to anybody who raises any question whatsoever about the safety of their products.

Ranged against these sorts of forces, the public certainly needs very adequate protection. The concern the Democrats are expressing with respect to this legislation is: is the protection being offered here adequate? We believe that in certain respects this legislation, while moving us forward considerably, falls short of the ideal.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take pleasure in joining this debate on the agricultural and veterinary chemicals legislation. The Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray), in his second reading speech, said that it is an historic occasion. I do not put it at quite that order of importance, but I suppose it approaches something of that kind. This package of bills came out of the Senate Select Committee on Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals in Australia, which was convened in 1990. That committee was constituted as a result of the pesticide in beef fiasco of the previous two years.

PARA.TAB: The pesticide in beef fiasco was a little overplayed by trade interests in places other than Australia. To a certain extent, pesticide in beef resulted from the availability of DDT at a very low price at the time. It was overused, especially in the potato growing areas. I believe some good came out of the pesticide in beef fiasco in the long run. It led to the Senate select committee inquiry, and it taught growers of beef to be a bit more careful about where they ran their cattle. I think all producers and consumers of beef have benefited from what happened at the time.

On 1 July 1991 the Commonwealth, states and territories agreed to a national registration scheme to replace the rather out of contact sort of situation where all the states and territories were operating in the field. On 1 July 1993 the Commonwealth took over evaluation of agricultural and veterinary chemicals. Then, of course, in July 1993 the National Registration Authority was established, which obviously honourable senators know about.

To my knowledge, the use of chemicals has been the biggest advance in agriculture—I do not have to tell you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that I am very involved in agriculture—over the last 10 or 12 years. I would say that 1984 saw the beginning of the pre-emergent chemicals and also the high use of knockdown chemicals in crop growing.

Pre-1984 we had post-emergent chemicals only and there was very little availability of knockdown chemicals, so land was cultivated far more and that caused a lot of breakdown in soil structure and, of course, a great use of fuel. The more chemicals are used, the less fuel is used and the less cultivation occurs.

That was the beginning of the rationalisation of costs. With the high increase in fuel prices, we had to look at ways of cutting those costs. With the knockdown method, people did not have to cultivate early to get rid of early weeds if there were early rains, and so forth. It was the real beginning of minimal cultivation, as already mentioned.

The levy bills under this national registration scheme aim at full cost recovery. You may remember, Mr Acting Deputy President, and from my knowledge, it was originally going to be spread over four years. We will now be in full cost recovery by 1995-96 with 80 per cent recovered by 1994-95.

In the last year for which figures are fully available, Australian agriculture consumed $720 million worth of chemicals in the crop growing sphere and $200 million worth of veterinary chemicals. That accounts for over $1 billion, so we are not talking about small stakes. We can say that it boosts production of crops by about $4 billion.

Allied with minimal cultivation through chemical use is the fertiliser boost, which I believe will probably be the biggest advance in crop growing of the last two years. It will probably go through for the next three or four years because of the advent of more intensive soil testing with greater availability of different specialised fertilisers. Of course, that has come about through the fact that there is some competition for Australian fertilisers.

Manufacturers have come on board in the last few years and that has caused the monopoly of Australian superphosphate manufacturers to disappear somewhat. I am thinking of Summit Chemicals in Western Australia, for instance, which started importing these specialised fertilisers. Of course, the established manufacturers have had to reduce their prices. I believe the next advance in crop growing will be the more assiduous use of specialised fertilisers at a more opportune time.

Having chemicals available makes crop growing a lot easier. When a farmer enters a paddock to put in his crop he uses, say, a knockdown chemical or a pre-emergent, he does his cultivating and then his seeding. He then shuts up the paddock and, unless he has to apply a bit of post-emergent—hopefully, not too much—he does not come back until it is time to harvest the crop.

The National Registration Authority claims to have a fast-track method of evaluating and registering new chemicals in Australia. That is very important. Knockdown and pre-emergent chemicals such as gleen, which first came on the scene in 1984, have been used to control rye grass and wild oats. We are now starting to see a resistance to those chemicals. Of course, we have had a build-up of rye grass toxicity in sheep. Introducing new chemicals must not be a slow process, otherwise we have to go right back and do a lot more cultivation, which will increase costs and reduce production. The fast-track method to get these new chemicals on the shelf is very much welcomed by Australian grain growers.

We also have to make sure that there is competition. I remember when gleen came along in 1984 or thereabouts. We trialled it in 1982 on a small area. But when this chemical was mass produced in 1984, it had no competition whatsoever. It did not have competition until the arrival of logran, which is somewhat of a generic sort of brand. It is very significant to note that the current price of gleen is almost exactly the same as it was in 1988. That is about the time that its competitor, logran, came onto the market. If we have new products, it is very important to have them evaluated quickly and registered so that we do not have one product sitting on its own.

The same can be said about the knockdown chemical Roundup, which was probably the second most effective chemical of this type to come along. Sprayseed was the first one, but it was very difficult and dangerous to handle. We had to use proper methods, otherwise we could have finished up with more than a great headache. When roundup came along, the competition between it and sprayseed caused the price to stay rather static. Of course, roundup itself now has a competitor in the generic glyphosphate. As I say, quick evaluation and registration of chemicals is very important if we are to have competition and ensure that farmers are not paying through the nose for chemicals. After all, chemicals are a very big item. I will come back to that later.

At the moment the cost of chemicals used by grain growers is getting somewhat towards the higher end of the scale. In the past, when there was minimal chemical use, fertilisers normally used to be the highest cost item of wheat growing, followed by fuel. Now in some cases the cost of chemicals is passing the cost of fertilisers and, certainly, it has gone past the cost of fuel. As I said before, if one uses more chemicals, less fuel is used. The cost of chemicals is a very big factor. An inquiry some time in the future into the cost of chemicals in Australia would not be out of order but, of course, that is not the topic of debate today.

Competition, as I have already said, tends to hold prices in check. In fact, I heard only last evening from a person who rang me that, because of the good competition that gleen has been getting from logran over the past two or three years, gleen's manufacturers have added an incentive. The manufacturers have said that if a crop sprayed with gleen is not harvested because of drought, or frost, or come what may, they will replace the chemical to put on the crop next year. I have not read the fine print, but this is something that has come out of the blue because of competition. I am hoping that logran will reciprocate next week. Fast-tracking is very important to create plenty of competition on the shelf and to keep cost down.

Chemicals are part and parcel of agriculture. I know that in the past our friends the Democrats and the Greens have advocated an alternative way of farming which will do away with fertilisers and chemicals altogether. Agriculture is very competitive these days. Farmers have to realise that farming without chemicals and without fertilisers is a good way to ensure that they go into liquidation.

I said earlier that the administration of the National Registration Authority is based on full cost recovery. But I believe safeguards should be built in to prevent this authority becoming another AQIS. We all know from debate in this chamber how AQIS has been operating. It has virtually been unaccountable to the parliament, to the users of its services, and to anyone else. It is probably not even accountable to itself. It has mushroomed and ballooned into an authority that does not really know where it is going and is adding to the cost of meat producers in Australia. I certainly hope that governments attempt to keep a lid on the costs and to make the National Registration Authority accountable and transparent. We have to make sure that it does not go the way of AQIS and a few other government bodies, semi-government bodies and statutory bodies, as this one is.

The National Registration Authority may consider that it is passing the cost back to the users of the scheme—that is, the manufacturers of chemicals. But I can assure the Senate from past experience—and I am sure other people have had similar experiences—that all of this is passed back to the end user. The end user, in this case, is the farmer, and he will be made to pay right down to the last cent. However, with proper monitoring, I believe that this can be controlled. Unfortunately, I cannot see that there is anything whatsoever in this legislation that will ensure that there is transparency.

However, I welcome the legislation that has resulted from a Senate select committee inquiry. I enjoyed very much my time on that committee with my colleagues. Probably this legislation is not the real answer to what we were, and still are, looking for. But I am sure that, with a couple of years of experience down the track, we will be able to look at the legislation again to make sure that it is doing the job that it is intended to do to the advantage not only of farmers but everyone else who uses chemicals and veterinary products. I do not use anywhere near as much veterinary products as I do agricultural chemicals. But all users of chemicals and veterinary products will benefit in the long term.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bell and Senator Coulter have already raised many concerns regarding this package of legislation. Senator Panizza, Senator Brownhill and Senator Tambling from the opposition have received the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Bill and cognate bills well. When a new system is being considered which is an advance over previous arrangements, it is difficult to know how to relate to the concerns and problems that may be present in it. Certainly the second reading speeches, the parts of the bills and explanatory memoranda sound good. That could be taken as an encouragement that the legislation has been set up in such a way as to look at the agricultural and veterinary chemicals management within our country.

PARA.TAB: This is a package of seven bills which are being considered together. I will illustrate one thing which looks good in the second reading speech on one of these bills. The Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) on behalf of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins) noted:

SPEECH.PARA: This legislative package extends the functions of the National Registration Authority for agricultural and veterinary chemicals . . . to include the registration and control of . . . products. The new functions have been developed in consultation with the states and territories to ensure a consistent approach to the assessment and control of chemical products.
Furthermore, the NRA is to have regard to the government's policy in relation to the principles of ecologically sustainable development.

Also the NRA will be required to comply with the policies of Commonwealth, state and territory governments that are determined under an agreement to be entered into between those governments for the purpose of this proposed Act and the AGVET codes.
Who could disagree with the rhetoric there or at least the lip-service? Unfortunately, underneath that there are concerns that need to be addressed; and I will be referring to them later.

PARA.TAB: I will mention a matter in passing but I will not touch on it in any great detail. It concerns the bill in this package which relates to the collection of a levy which covers cost recovery. There is a four-year period phase-in of the way the National Registration Authority will be able to manage the cost recovery associated with the bill. That does sound impressive. The bill that is within this package identifies how liability for payment of a levy charge will be determined and the amount that will be imposed. Generally speaking, liability for the levy will be based on the sale or disposal of chemical products in Australia. Cost recovery and the implication that it concerns the sale or disposal of chemical products do not and should not convey any moral permission or control that allows these chemicals to be so regarded as not to take in community concerns and the manufacturing standards being set up by the NRA.

While the Greens (WA) approve the development of principles, guidelines and standards which are supported by legislation, there is considerable concern that the present legislation does not go nearly far enough in the direction of community right to know and ecologically sustainable development processes. Senator Coulter has already pointed out that because the legislation is being established by a federal rather than a national process—state agreements make up the legislation—Commonwealth-state agreements can be used to tie the hands of any state that wishes to be progressive. So on the one hand it may well pull up those who may bring the standards down but, on the other hand, it may well impede developments that can be very important.

We are concerned that the mechanisms by which this legislation is established should be able to be improved quite dramatically on those currently represented here. I have already mentioned the positives. I have said it sounds good—but is it? I want to indicate that there are positives—and there are community groups. As we have already heard from my colleagues in this place, many sections of the community welcome such legislation and the development it represents.

There are also people who really welcome the initiatives that the chemical industry has taken to look at its sometimes very doubtful heritage in our world. I would like to quote from some conference notes by Mr Tom Reynolds of the Puritan Churchill Chemical Company. He presented a key speech to Parliamentarians for Global Action, talking about the development of the chemical weapons convention. His speech highlights the importance of the chemical industry worldwide. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: From its earliest days, the chemical industry has had a global impact, both with respect to its products and its technology, both of which flowed easily around the world. This remains true today, the chemical industry is truly global, and seeks to ensure that its products and technology still flow easily around the world.
He goes on to point out that eight of the 10 top chemical companies are European. He also says:

The chemical industry now recognises that it must accept social responsibility for its actions and take into account the effects of these actions on people and the planet. The Australian Chemical Industry Council in concert with the chemical industry in many parts of the world has developed and adopted a "Responsible Care" initiative to enshrine this concern in its day to day operations. This view was certainly not always held by the industry or the community in the early days, however, all our attitudes have changed towards conservation and the environment in the last 20 years.

The input of Mr Tom Reynolds was extremely positive, as is the initiative that he referred to in that speech. I want to acknowledge that, as I go on to look at some of the negatives in relation to this legislation and to the community feedback that the Greens have received. One comment is from the Toxin Action Group. It notes in a press release in February this year that it believes double standards rob rural workers' rights. It points out that community and rural groups are incensed over the federal government's decision to provide them less protection and less access to information than have industrial workers in the new agricultural and veterinary chemical bills 1993. The release states:

"There is absolutely no excuse for the Federal Government in this new legislation to give rural workers and their communities less rights and protection than their counterparts in industry. We are shocked that the new Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Bill has not adopted the Worksafe standard for access to information on chemicals." spokesperson for TAG, Ms Grinter said.

She talks about how the preparation of the new bill regulates the registration of new chemicals and reviews old and outdated chemicals. She believes that the continuation of secrecy clauses and companies' rights to refuse information is to the detriment of community groups.

PARA.TAB: She also talks about approaches that have been made to board members of the National Registration Authority. The people were assured that their concerns would be addressed, yet the final draft of the legislation does not reflect the concerns that have been raised. This group has also raised a concern, which I think was mentioned earlier, that there was a very limited consultation process. They were concerned that it was mere tokenism and did not really support the words that have led people to hope that the National Registration Authority was a new broom that would sweep through the outdated agricultural and veterinary chemicals section of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, to be replaced with a more open and transparent method of consultation.

I will go on to some of the detailed concerns expressed by community groups. I will refer back to that concern about protection for industrial workers by the worksafe provision and the fact that rural communities are being denied the right to access product content details. I will go further into the detail of these concerns.

I will mention some issues of concern that have been raised in relation to these bills. First, there is a failure to have represented in the structure of the board of the National Registration Authority representatives of the Commonwealth Environment Protection Agency, public health agencies and conservationists. A second issue of concern is the extremely important and integral issue of commercial-in-confidence data which has not been addressed to the satisfaction of some of the community groups. The community is still denied the right to access product content formulation details.

A number of parents within the organisations have expressed some of these concerns. For reasons of children's health they require immediate access to data on product ingredients, particularly in relation to solvent and surfactant content. Obviously this has a major community impact in relation to children's health and allergic reactions.

We also consider it an essential role for the NRA to assess company claims for commercial-in-confidence data, particularly in the light of the introduction of proprietary rights in Australia. The NRA should be responsible for the development of procedures for easy access to such information by the community. This concern was also supported by peak environment groups which were involved in briefing sessions with the NRA. Strong views have been expressed that the NRA should accept a similar policy to the current Worksafe national policy statement on the commercial confidentiality of data relating to workplace substances. There appears to be no justification for agricultural workers and associated rural communities being afforded less access to data and occupational health protection than other segments of the community.

The third point of concern is the absence of appeal rights for the community in response to decisions made by the NRA. The requirement to prove standing for the Administrative Appeals Tribunal would severely limit any access to this body, particularly with the sometimes limited availability of community groups to legal expertise and, occasionally, to the legal aid that may be required.

The issue of public participation generally within the act is of concern, as the NRA appears to have the discretionary powers to either permit public involvement or not. Public participation should be ensured as a right throughout the bill.

A different group, the North Coast Environment Council, considered that the concept of both precautionary principle or pesticide reduction must be addressed in the proposed act. Senator Bell's amendment would address that omission. The Greens intend to support the Australian Democrat amendments and are very disappointed with the lack of support that has apparently been expressed on the part of the government to look at those amendments and incorporate them in this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —We didn't get them until yesterday.

—I am glad to hear that it is only the shortage of time that is exercising the minister's mind. If the minister is prepared to incorporate some of those principles, we would be happy to oblige with an adjournment to allow that time. Along with the environment groups that have expressed concerns, the Greens consider that the precautionary principle and the principle of pesticide reduction should underlie the aims and actions of the NRA, and that statements to this effect should be included in amendments to its functions and powers.

PARA.TAB: A final concern—I shall raise some others later—is that the North Coast Environment Council considers the lack of outlined monitoring procedures for chemicals once they have been registered will result in a system that has no quality control and no ongoing audit process. While this aspect of the bill may be a state responsibility, monitoring procedures should be formally described within the bill.

This relates to Senator Coulter's concern that, once this legislation is in place, because it has this federal aspect it may not allow states to take the due monitoring courses they should take. So there is a suggestion here that that kind of monitoring procedure could be set up and provided for in the legislation to assist states to recognise its vital importance.

I have some questions which I will possibly put during the committee stage of this bill. But I want to finish on a positive note. I have a message from Householders for Safe Pesticide Use that in general it supports the NRA report and recommendations but would have preferred an immediate ban on organochlorines. The restrictions on imports beginning in April 1994, with the complete cessation of imports in September 1994, are likely to result in a relatively early end to the use of these chemicals across Australia.

That organisation wants to make sure that that recommendation is followed. It notes that the ACT has already imposed a complete ban on organochlorines and that Western Australia, where alternatives are better established than in any other state, is unaccountably dragging its feet. The Northern Territory appears to be the main stumbling block to the Australia-wide ban, and that is also noted in relation to setting up this particular legislation.

We can only hope that the commitment that Simon Crean made when he was the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy to banning these persistent and hazardous chemicals will be continued through the NRA's emphasis and under the new minister for that portfolio, Senator Collins. It is very clear that the continued use of organochlorines, even if only for termite control, is likely to pose a threat to the `clean green' image federal and state authorities are promoting for Australian produce and the environment in which it is grown.

I conclude by saying that the Greens have an ambivalent attitude towards this legislation. We know that it has the support of the Senate. We wish to signify our concern that this bill does not go far enough in the direction we feel is certainly called for at present. We had hoped it would lead us in an even more progressive direction than that in which we are currently going. So we await the responses to the amendments that have been proposed by the Democrats and the result of the committee stage before we decide whether to support the bill. At the moment it seems to us that there are some very notable omissions that do not give us the kind of reassurance we would like to have—namely, that the words of the legislation are matched by political will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry Sen The Hon N.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —In concluding this debate on the second reading of the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemical Bill and cognate bills, I will respond to some of the comments expressed by Senator Chamarette. I am somewhat concerned at the Greens' attitude of ambivalence towards this legislation. It is a poor approach by the Greens because this is a significant piece of legislation. Senator Chamarette may not be aware of the background and the consultations that have taken place. I want to rebut criticism that consultation has not been as extensive as it should have been. This process commenced with a Senate select committee in 1988. And here we are, five years later, following very extensive consultation by the Senate committee, by the government and consultations between the federal government and the states and all interested parties.

PARA.TAB: If Senator Chamarette defines `consultation' as taking the attitude `Well, you didn't agree with me, therefore you did not consult', then she is right. But certainly there has been consultation over a period of five years and, given the importance of this legislation, it was critical that consultation should have occurred.

This is an unusual debate in that four senators who have spoken in this debate, as I understand it, were involved in the committee in 1988 which reported on agricultural and veterinary chemicals. They include Senator Coulter, Senator Brownhill and Senator Panizza. That committee was certainly before my time in this place, and it was certainly before Senator Chamarette's time, but I think we should place that on the record.

Much of the content of the proposed legislation reflects the recommendations made by that Senate committee. In fact, 12 of its recommendations are covered by provisions of the bills before the Senate. It is a good example of the effective work that most Senate committees do. I do not say all because I have some criticisms on some aspects of the Senate committee system, but that is a matter which should be considered at another time. Nevertheless, this reflects the very important and critical role that Senate committees can play in the process.

I thank all honourable senators who have indicated their support. Senator Bell has some amendments but, at the end of the day, I think he would concede that this is progress. The legislation may not go as far as he would like to take it. I recognise the more responsible attitude he has taken. I do not think Senator Bell would describe his attitude in the same way as the Greens described theirs—ambivalent. Senator Bell has conceded that this legislation represents significant progress, if not the progress that the Democrats are looking for.

The passage of these bills will bring very significant changes to the regulation of agricultural and veterinary chemicals in Australia. The provisions are aimed at improving efficiency. Such provisions include statutory deadlines for the processing of applications and penalties should those deadlines not be met. The system will become much more open and transparent with the provision of public release summaries and a facility for the public to nominate chemicals for inclusion in the review of existing chemical programs.

The national registration scheme also represents another milestone in the government's program of micro-economic reform. It is producing benefits for agriculture and the chemical industry, contributing to the increased competitiveness of Australian industries and improving the safeguards placed on these chemicals for all Australians. The scheme also includes new provisions not possible under the previous two-tiered clearance system. It includes: controls on the import, export and manufacture of agvet chemicals; compensation provisions for certain data which will underpin the review of the existing chemicals program; a national focus on the issue; and improved information flows.

This scheme will place Australia among the few nations of the world with a formal minor use program to address the difficult issues of chemical use in minor crops. These achievements are the result of concerted effort from all concerned, with a high level of consultation with stakeholders and cooperation from many interested groups. Those groups include rural sector groups, consumers, the chemical industry and, in particular, the states and territories. This will provide Australia with a word-class registration system which will ensure that the health and environment aspects of agvet chemicals are maintained and that our rural exports are protected. I thank those honourable senators who contributed in the debate for their support and I commend the legislation to the Senate.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Bell's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: in a major newspaper circulating in each capital city.

PARA.TAB: I am informed it is already done 30 times, so it is already costing some tens of thousands of dollars. The legislation provides that a mailing list will be kept of all of the main interest groups. A relevant interest group on agricultural and chemical matters that notifies us will be directly mailed. This is a much more cost effective way of dealing with the issue.

Normally it would be desirable to advertise as much as possible, but the phenomenal cost of the Democrat approach—involving literally millions of dollars—is not a cost effective way of notifying the public and these various interest groups. Sadly, I have to rebuke Senator Bell and the Democrats for putting forward one of the whackiest amendments that we have had in the Senate this year, involving as it does a ridiculous amount of money.

I will touch briefly on matters raised in these amendments and in the debate at large. The issue of funds being made available for the National Registration Authority to enable it to perform community service obligations essential to the evaluation and control of agricultural and veterinary chemical products is a paraphrase of another amendment.

In agreeing to establish the national registration scheme, the government also agreed that the scheme should be funded 100 per cent by industry. Again I have to rebuke the Democrats. I would have thought that where commercial benefit is gained by companies in selling chemicals, the cost of its regulation for the public good should be met by the industry itself and not out of general taxpayers' funds. The government is a strong advocate of that. I am surprised the Democrats are suggesting that taxpayers should be subsidising commercial operations out of government funds. That is the effect of what the Democrats are asking for. Clearly that suggestion is not acceptable to the government.

In the opening statement we gave a commitment that there will be a review of the legislation after 18 or 20 months. This will include an assessment of cost recovery, including community service obligations. These assessments are best made when some operational time has elapsed to evaluate what community service obligation there is, if any, and whether there should be a government contribution. I am certainly aware that there are other instances of charging policy on the part of government—for example, in AQIS. I do not want to develop that debate beyond saying that it is an existing government operation that is phasing in a charge and that the community obligation is regularly assessed. That is also done with the Fisheries Management Authority. We are best able to assess the community obligations, if they exist, when we have had some operational experience. TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Clause 6, page 3, subclause (1), at the end of proposed paragraph 7(1A), add the following paragraph:

3.Clause 6, page 4, subclause (3), proposed subsection 7(4), line 14, after "particular," insert "to the precautionary principle and"
