There is no need for me to rehearse the particulars of each of the amendments but I shall speak to them in general. The purpose of the amendments was rehearsed in my contribution on the second reading. Briefly, the purpose of our first amendment to clause 6 of the bill seeks to deliver to the package a convenient place for public contribution to provide feedback on the use aspect of chemicals. It brings into operation the precautionary principle.

PARA.TAB: The bill glibly speaks of the precautionary principle or the principle of ecologically sustainable development, but acceptance of this amendment will deliver the implementation of that principle. We should monitor how the chemicals are used in real life—certainly not the TV program. The `public'—the group of people who are using these chemicals—should have a capacity to provide the information on the effects of that usage. At the moment the process is the other way around. Instead of providing a facility which is easily accessible and also registered and calculated by legislation, it is almost a case of avoiding the opportunity for the public to contribute. That is the purpose of amendment No. 1.

Amendments 2, 3 and 4 insert a specific reference to the precautionary principle into the definition in this bill, and I think it reads reasonably well. It is a definition which I lifted from the government's draft national strategy for ecologically sustainable development prepared in June 1992 by the ecologically sustainable development steering committee. The definition provides an illumination which is not displayed in the bills. The committee heard evidence as to why that was the case. Too many presumptions are made and too many `glib' agreements entered into without their spelling out what is required. Certainly the guiding principles would be much clearer if this amendment were accepted.

I could spend the time of the committee further developing these reasons but both the coalition and the government have made it clear that they are not prepared to accept any amendments. I reinforce Senator Coulter's contention and plead for honourable senators to be very wary of the fundamental shortcoming of this approach to legislation. We have been placed in a situation where amendment is difficult; it is discouraged. I will not say that we have been intimidated to the extent that we are afraid to move amendments, but we have been strongly discouraged from moving amendments.

Senator Tambling did not appear to be cowed by the threat of it having to go back to the states and territories. However, in both the government's and the coalition's contribution there was the concern that so much had been invested—a mass of time and negotiation—that, to use the words of the chairman of the NRA in evidence before the committee, upsetting the applecart was something to be avoided. Senator Coulter is right to draw the attention of the committee to our tendency to deliberate upon legislation which has already been assembled and intertwined and has the collective weight of state approval behind it. I would hope that the reluctance of the government and the coalition to accept these amendments is based on content and not on that fear. Neither the government nor the coalition look that afraid to me but it is a thing that we should be considering.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are not.

—I know Senator Sherry gave a reason for not accepting the previous amendment. I will just take a second to address that because I think he got it wrong, actually. I accept that there is a vast cost involved in telling people what the government is doing by putting notices in the newspaper. That seems a reasonable defence against accepting our worthwhile attempt to tell people what was going on.

PARA.TAB: His other defence was that the taxpayer should not have to fund commercial operations. That is not what was being asked at all. It was a question of who is the user of this whole legislation. The user that is being asked to pay is not only the producer, not only the farmer and not only the consumer of the chemicals. The user is the whole community because the whole community is safeguarded by this legislation. The whole community derives benefit from knowing that our food is safe and that our farm practices are safe. The user is the whole community, which derives benefit from knowing that Australia can actually match the rhetoric of Minister Crean by being clean and green. Therefore, the whole community, in deriving benefit, should contribute to this National Registration Authority scheme.

In fact, I have a private member's bill which implements coalition policy that such schemes only be funded by the contributor to 50 per cent. I intend to revitalise that private member's bill at a suitable occasion to see whether the coalition can welcome its own policy—the policy that I read before the last election. I do not know what the policy is now, but it seemed to be a good policy at that time. I could not resist tackling the assertion that the parliamentary secretary made to me. I will not talk any more about these amendments. I think I have made it clear what their purpose is, and I know what the numbers are for them.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I was a bit surprised at the allegation that there is some underhand deal or approach on this matter between the government and the opposition, and a little amused by it because it is simply not true.
—I was just looking at the numbers.

—Certainly the numbers are clear—you are going to lose on this occasion and on other occasions you will win. Some you lose, some you win. The weight of argument, as well as the numbers, is overwhelmingly against the Democrats on this occasion. There are sound arguments for not accepting the amendments, given that there has been a five-year process of consultation, given that the principles embodied in the legislation emerged from a Senate committee, and given that the federal government does not have sole constitutional power in this area. States are a reality; they have constitutional rights. We can disagree at times about that but the facts are the facts—states have rights in this area. They needed to be consulted and a consensus needed to be developed. I do not think that holding that up as an important element in securing the passage of this legislation is in any way a threat, intimidation or anything like that; it is just a fact of life that we have to deal with in Australia as best we can.

PARA.TAB: With regard to the amendment that seeks to provide a facility by which the public may submit information, Senator Bell may or may not be aware that the reason we will not accept this is that it is unnecessary. At its most recent meeting, the board of the NRA decided to establish, in cooperation with New Zealand, a suspected adverse chemical reaction register. As I am advised, this will be established in the next six months. The procedures and format have been agreed with New Zealand and will be implemented. In addition, health data is already being collected by the National Injury Surveillance Unit of the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare and Worksafe Australia's farmsafe program—a national strategy aimed at improving occupational health and safety on farms. Again, I am advised that any person from the public can submit concerns they have about chemicals to these organisations. We do not believe that the amendment as proposed is necessary.

The major comments made by Senator Bell went to the precautionary principle and inserting a new subsection. We believe that that amendment is unnecessary. As I noted in the introductory statement, the NRA is required in the performance of its functions to have regard for the Commonwealth government's policy on ecologically sustainable development. That policy includes seven guiding principles, one of which is the precautionary principle. Therefore, it is taken into account in that form in this legislation. It is important that equal weight be accorded to all those principles, not just to one of them. Certainly ecologically sustainable development is a very important principle but the other principles are important as well. It is important that they are all accorded equal weight in that particular policy, as it is expressed and reflected by this legislation, and that one is not amplified over the other. For those reasons, we are opposing the amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Sherry) has just said, there has been no collusion or collaboration between the coalition and the government but there certainly has been an agreement between us on this occasion as to our stance on the Democrat amendment. That is simply because common sense should prevail.

PARA.TAB: The amendments proposed by the Democrats are very much the sorts of amendments we have come to expect on these sorts of issues that come up from time to time because of the specific agendas and policies of the Democrats. Unfortunately, as usual, the Democrats do not recognise the constitutional constraints that apply, and that in this instance responsibility rests with the states. Now that an agreement has been reached, after 25 years, it would be a real pity to jeopardise those arrangements and that timing. Whilst the Democrats may from time to time attempt to write a new environmental testament, I do not see why on this occasion we should accept the gospel of either John or Robert.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to speak briefly on this and recount my experience, particularly in view of what Senator Tambling has just said. Some honourable senators might know that until 1980 I worked as a research scientist in the area of occupational health. I would like to recount just one episode of many I had which dealt with a government department in South Australia.

PARA.TAB: The engineering and water supply department was responsible for the installation and management of the water supply and sewerage in Adelaide and also in country areas in South Australia. This particular department used very large pipes in one of its installations for the carriage of water and sewage. To protect these pipes against rusting it virtually bandaged them in a mixture of pitch.

The workers became aware that pitch was one of those things that had been identified as a human carcinogen—a substance capable of causing cancer. They contacted the Health Commission in South Australia and asked whether some work could be done to estimate the risks to which they were exposed. The Health Commission had no facilities at that stage to carry out the sorts of tests that were necessary and, through the nursing sister who worked at this E&WS establishment, I was asked whether I could carry out some tests to estimate the actual risks to the men who were doing this work.

The men were involved in heating the pitch to a high temperature, leaning over the 44-gallon or 200-litre drum of melted pitch, bucketing it out, layering it up on these very large pipes, and then turning the bandages around the pipes to hold the pitch onto them. It was possible, with the laboratory facilities that I then had, to estimate the amount of cancer-causing agent in the pitch before and after it was heated. It worked out that in one 44-gallon drum of pitch there was the release of the equivalent of four million cigarettes, and these men were working in a relatively confined space, leaning over this drum, and being exposed to this material.

The reason for telling this story is that when my report went to the department, that practice was stopped immediately and the workmen there were no longer exposed to this cancer-causing risk. However, the engineering and water supply department then contracted this work out to private people, who carried on the same activity. The workers there were not told—and this is the point I am making—of the risks involved or of the work that had been done in this area.

Subsequently, when the Health Commission, another government department in South Australia, undertook to do some of this work, it chose not to come to me for an estimate of the risks to those workers and also to provide the information—quite contrary to the rules—to the employer but not to the union concerned.

So with that as background I would simply point out that there is very much a need for people to know, and that this ability for members of the public to submit information lies at the heart of the proper protection of the public. From my personal experience I must say that one cannot rely on those organisations, even those run by state governments and charged with the responsibility of looking after the public health, to carry out that obligation. I have had that experience with at least two government departments in South Australia.

Therefore, I would make a strong plea to Senator Tambling to review what he has said in the light of what I have just recounted. We are not putting up these amendments out of some airy fairy notion that they might be a good thing; they come out of actual experience with chemicals by somebody who has worked over some years in the field of occupational health.

TALK.START.PARA: —A lot of practices and polices have changed since 1980.

—Yes, certainly. This occurred in 1979, but if Senator Tambling is suggesting that these sorts of practices cannot occur in the future, then I think he really does have his head up in the clouds and does not have his feet on the ground at all. These sorts of things can go on, and when, as I said in my speech in the second reading debate, there is such an enormous amount of financial interest associated with the use of these agricultural chemicals—the sale of them is measured in tens of millions of dollars worth of product—and one is dealing with very jealous, competitive companies, then it is very important that at the earliest opportunity the public is able to bring this information forward, and to make it more generally available.

—In my experience in relation to these matters, in my reading, in the discussions of the committee, and also in consideration of the evidence in the submissions that were given, I have found that the people who have been responsible for overseeing the management of chemicals in Australia have done less than a wonderful job. There has been a fair bit of baggage carried over time by these people, and a lot of mistrust has developed. That is a concern of the Democrats and the Greens. I was very much impressed by the chairman in his attitude to these matters, and his determination to see that questions of labelling and use—in so far as the NRA would be able to assert its authority—would be properly carried out. Obviously the government's attitude and that of the opposition is that these people on the NRA should be given the opportunity to do just that and that the provision within this group of bills will arm them to do so. If they do not do that in a short period—18 months—we will have a look at the way in which the legislation is operating and we will make whatever adjustments need to be made.

PARA.TAB: Somebody might say, `A lot can happen in 18 months'. Let me suggest that a lot has happened over the past 30 years and we have not got to this stage yet. I think that now we have, it is a good thing. One has only to look at the fact that we used DDT in this country some years after it was banned all around the world to have some appreciation of the arguments being advanced by the Greens and the Democrats. However I, like the minister, believe that we should pass the legislation in its current form, give it an opportunity to operate, and give the authority the opportunity to show us that it will do the job.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The bill before the Senate is the Training Guarantee (Administration) Amendment Bill. On behalf of the opposition, I indicate that the Liberal and National parties will not oppose this bill at the second reading. It has a number of positive innovations adding flexibility—making, as some have claimed, this odious measure a little more business friendly.

PARA.TAB: The opposition still wants to abolish the whole levy arrangement because of its remaining inflexibilities, the burden it places upon business and the distortion of some areas of training. I will refer in my speech to a wide range of expert and business opinion—indeed, even trade union opinion—that this whole measure be suspended. In the committee stage I will move on behalf of the opposition three groups of amendments, and which I will outline these three groups of amendments in my speech.

The bill has no financial impact. There is no additional cost to government or to the taxpayer as a result of it. To a large extent, the bill in some measure fulfils the promise given by the government to business during the last election campaign. The government understood that this training levy was odious and was seen to be counterproductive by many areas of the Australian economy and, accordingly, some hints at making the burden lighter were indicated by the Labor Party during the election campaign. Some of these promises have been translated to the legislation that is now before us.

Some of the flexibilities added to this basically flawed bill provide for an allowance to average training expenditure by any business over a two-year period rather than that business having to spend the money within the financial year under review as defined. It will allow any unspent money to be picked up in the following year. In due course, I will move an amendment that seeks to extend that averaging of two years levy over two years to three years levy over three years.

Another amendment in the bill will allow a range of businesses to be grouped, as defined in the bill, so that their spending for training levy purposes can be averaged across the whole group and not precisely one business by one business. That is a welcome innovation and adds some flexibility.

Change to the definitions regarding equipment will allow an extended range of equipment used by businesses for training purposes to be eligible under the provisions of the act. They will include the use of equipment that is on lease or hire—flexibility that has been sought for some years.

The act that is to be amended is about four years old. It started on 1 July 1990. In due course in the committee stage, on behalf of the Liberal and National parties, I will seek to move an amendment providing for cessation of the whole bill on 1 July 1994, which means that business in this country has had to suffer a four-year penalty upon business..

The Liberal and National parties—indeed, I am sure all honourable senators—wish to see appropriate investment in training by business throughout Australia. Rather than having counterproductive measures such as this one that has been in existence for nearly four years, we would rather see more general incentives offered to business. The best incentive of all is that the only way to be internationally competitive, the only way to have a medium and long-term future and prosperity in any business, is for proper investments to be made in the most important asset of any business. I refer to the skill of its own management and employees. We believe this outcome will be better achieved by not having an overregulated, distorting burden upon business, such as this requirement for a levy on any business that does not meet the training guarantee.

The bill will also bring to an end discrimination against people aged over 21 being trained in a business, and we welcome that move. We welcome all the measures in the bill, but they do not go anywhere near far enough to satisfy the Liberal and National parties. They make a bad act slightly less bad.

The third opposition amendment to the bill will allow more extensive grouping of businesses that are legitimate under company law. In the committee stage I will deal in more detail with the three amendments—namely, the extension to a three-year averaging; the extension of grouping to be more sensible, more flexible; and a group of amendments that would terminate the whole legislation on 1 July this year.

One of the penalties that this act brings to business is the cost of record keeping, which process takes a lot of time and a lot of money. That record keeping does not add a jot to the training of personnel within a company or to their skills. Sometimes Labor governments kid themselves—they do not kid the Australian people—that just because certain monitoring goes on, there is substance in the outcome of what is being monitored. It is more often the case that by chewing up time and money the process of record keeping leads to a counterproductive diversion of precious resources.

Quantity is also no guarantee of quality. Even government senators opposite, such as Senator Carr, no doubt would aspire to the achievement of quality rather than just quantity in the training given to personnel in every business. There is a problem when legislation seeks to define, measure and gain quality outcomes. We need quality outcomes and well trained personnel in businesses, but certainly we do not need intervening, overregulating, counterproductive measures such as this legislation represents—and, I fear, will continue to represent even with these positive improvements.

The views that I have put are not those of only the Liberal and National parties. I want to cite seven major authorities in Australia who are currently critical of this whole act and who want to see it ended. The first authority is Mr Kelty, the most important figure in the trade union movement. He led a task force on regional development. On page 32 of the task force report, it states:

SPEECH.PARA: Regional employers said the TGL had created an administrative burden and was failing to provide the training for which it was designed.
This is Mr Kelty. This is the government's own task force on regional development. The report goes on to state:

The Task Force was told that while many employers were committed to providing training for all employees, other employers were distorting the intent of the program by spending training money on, for example, executive "training weekends" in luxury resorts. The Task Force believes that a new system is needed to direct training money into where it is most needed—the traineeship system. Given the problems with the TGL and the fact that it has not provided training for the group which really needs it, the Task Force believes it should be suspended.

That is what Kelty thinks. He supports the amendments that I will be moving—that we suspend the training guarantee levy. Maybe any hesitancy amongst government senators to support my amendments and to see an end to this whole legislation by July will be because they have it in mind to do the same thing in the May budget. Will the Treasurer (Mr Willis) actually abolish the training guarantee levy in the May budget this year? To be safe, let us accept the amendments that I will be moving so that we see the end of this legislation on 1 July of this year at the latest.

PARA.TAB: The second authority is the Industries Commission. It is another very important advisory body to the government and to all Australians. In its 1992-93 annual report, it stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Yet the efficacy and efficiency of a compulsory levy can be questioned. One recent study concluded that the levy is a blunt instrument for achieving its objectives and has recommended a move away from compulsion and penalties . . .

The third authority is the evidence that has arisen from surveys of businesses about the ineffectiveness of the training guarantee levy. A study by Professor Charles Noble of Charles Sturt University on businesses in the Albury-Wodonga area found that 81 per cent of firms surveyed said that if the levy was abolished there would be no reduction. There would be no reduction if the levy was abolished. In his evidence to the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training on this bill, Professor Noble said that he thought it better to look at training alternatives other than the training guarantee levy. Professor Noble's submission to the committee stated:

The training Guarantee played an important role in emphasising the benefits of training, especially for firms that have under-invested in human resources development. It is doubtful if this approach is the most appropriate way of encouraging training in the longer term. Even with the amendments now being considered it is likely that some training expenditure will be wasted.
This is an expert on the matter. This is evidence that has led these concerns to be taken up by the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training. Professor Noble goes on to state:
Rather than persisting with a review of the TG, it should be abolished.
It should be abolished. That is the sentiment expressed not only by Mr Kelty, but also by Professor Noble.

PARA.TAB: The fourth authority is Professor Jim Gaite and Ms Karen Beresford of the University of South Australia. They have researched the training needs of small business and have found small businesses' expenditure on training has been little affected by the training guarantee. They found that the training guarantee levy provides little incentive for small businesses to engage more fully in training activity and that the administration and record keeping required was disproportionately burdensome.

The fifth authority is a study by Tim Henson of Monash University's David Syme faculty of business. That study found that only four companies in 100 had anything positive to say about the training guarantee levy. In his report, he stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Respondents from all industry sectors stated that they are now simply documenting what was already done prior to the introduction of the Act.

The sixth authority is the Business Council of Australia. It regards the levy as an inappropriate way to encourage industry to train personnel. The seventh authority is the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry. It has called for the scrapping of the training guarantee levy. This is expressed not only by Mr Kelty of the trade union movement, but also by the Business Council of Australia and the Australian Chamber of Commerce—end it, abolish it! What are the odds that the government will actually hear the overwhelming number of voices and that the Treasurer will do this in the May budget?

PARA.TAB: I conclude by making it clear that this has been the view of the Liberal and National parties all the way along. I remember the original debate in 1990, before the levy started operating on 1 July. We believed then that, whilst it is vital that there be investment in training in every area of Australian business and that we must be internationally competitive, this measure was not the way to get the best results. That was our view then; it has been our view every year since. It is our view now. We find the whole concert of Australian industry and business—large businesses and small businesses—academic and independent researchers, and Mr Kelty all agreeing with us.

The training guarantee levy has failed. That is clear from all the evidence. Even the government's own advisory bodies have, at the least, grave reservations and, more typically, they call for its abolition. It is with this in mind that I will go on in the committee stage to move the three groups of amendments that I have indicated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr Sen K.J.

The amendments made to the Training Guarantee (Administration) Act have been welcomed by small business. As Senator Teague has indicated, there has been some serious discussion about these issues before the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, of which I am a member. So it is quite a generous package of measures. No wonder small business has welcomed these measures. I note that members of the opposition are saying that they do not really oppose the amendments; what they oppose is the principle of the act.

The objections, essentially, were ideological. In that sense, the dispute essentially is ideological. TALK.START.PARA: —I would say it is a practical estimate; it is not ideological.

—As Senator Teague has indicated, the question of a practical estimate is a broader one. I will later give some examples to demonstrate why that is so inadequate.

PARA.TAB: This government has said, in broad terms, that it too disagrees with that approach. It has indicated that the act will continue and its provisions will be subject to further review. Some honourable senators, such as Senator Bell, have sought to reform the provisions and operations of this act and have sought a stricter definition of what constitutes legitimate training. They have sought the establishment of a body to monitor the scheme. As Senator Bell indicated in the committee bulletin of February 1994, in general he supported the provisions but thought there needed to be further improvements. For the Liberal Party, the issue is one of abolition.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what you are going to do anyway. You are going to abolish it anyway.
—No, that is not what is being proposed. Mr Charles, in the other place, summed up the attitude of the Liberal party in this regard. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: But on this side of the House, while we oppose the act, we said that we would take time to consider it. We have and it should be scrapped.

That essentially has been the position of those opposite for the last couple of years. In my judgment that is another example of the way in which the Liberal Party is operating within a policy vacuum. Particularly in education—which disturbs me greatly—a real position has not been put forward by the conservative parties about the way to advance public education, and training in particular, and the way the government legitimately should be involved in that process.

PARA.TAB: There are complaints and whingeing and whining about whether people are ripping off the scheme. We are not seeing substantial issues of policy debate which one would expect from an opposition that is serious about presenting substantial issues to this parliament.

The Labor government, on the other hand, remains firmly committed to producing a highly skilled work force. Part of that is the training guarantee levy. As has been indicated by Senator Teague, this measure was introduced 3 1/2 years ago. I believe that the training guarantee levy remains a very effective vehicle for the achievement of that aim of producing a highly skilled work force.

However, that is not to say it is perfect. As part of a consultative process, a reference group has been established to inform and seek views of the major stakeholders in this area. Some of the major industry representatives have expressed concerns to the government. The government, of course, is moving to address those issues.

When the original bill was introduced in August 1990, the minister said then that the scheme would need to be reviewed after a period of operation, to ensure it meets its original objectives. That review is currently under way and will conclude in October 1994. It will provide an opportunity for interested groups to make further comments on its findings. I trust that it will be the catalyst for broad community debate about the whole question of training and the most effective way to achieve the stated objectives.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Kelty?

PARA.TAB: We saw recently a National Safety Council of Australia study which showed that the lack of training for people at work was leading directly to the deaths and maiming of workers. DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Department of Employment, Education and Training

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the higher education funding for the 1994-96 triennium. I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: This particular document sets out how the government intends to spend money in higher education over the next three years. The amount intended to be spent in 1996 involves $5 billion in allocations—an increase of $66.1 million per year. The coalition has considerable concerns about the directions indicated by this document.

PARA.TAB: Over the last six years, there have been incredible changes in the higher education sector. They can be best summarised by saying that the government has provided insufficient resources for the expansion that has taken place. The disturbing thing about this document is that it shows a continuation of this very worrying trend. I wish to highlight a few points that the document makes about what our universities are doing in areas of importance to the future of this country.

My first point relates to something that Senator Teague talked about a little earlier in relation to another document—research infrastructure in this country. As Senator Teague pointed out, it is completely inadequate. Projections show that this inadequacy will continue into the future. For research infrastructure, the government has what it calls mechanisms A, B and C. Mechanism A relates to the support of Australian Research Council grants. We have a shocking situation in this country at the moment where only 20 per cent of applicants for grants gain funding, even though it is commonly agreed that at least 40 per cent of the applications are very worthy of funding. Research efforts go down the drain because this government is not prepared to support them.

Mechanism B relates to the old college institutes that recently became universities. It was to enable these institutions to catch up. Of course, the amount of money which has been put into this has been inadequate. The government, after three years, is now proposing to phase out this money. These institutions will not become full-blown research institutions. They will be greatly disadvantaged for other reasons which I will point out a little later. There is also the danger that we could return to the old binary system.

Probably the government's greatest inadequacy in this area has been in relation to libraries. The Boston Consulting Group recommended for this type of infrastructure, mechanism C, that another $125 million be spent annually on it. The government's response to this is to spend $3.5 million. We heard tonight from the AVCC that it is a bit of a pea and thimble trick because the government has actually, through the research quantum, grabbed back another $19.5 million. So it appears as though the government has increased the funding slightly when it has really decreased it.

There are some extremely worrying trends in the research area. Overall, probably the most worrying thing about this document is the way it stunts overall growth of this sector. Obviously, the government is sending out a signal to the community that it is approaching the limits of its capacity to fund higher education from public moneys. One of the reasons is that it is not allowing a whole source of other funding which could come into higher education to come into this sector.

This area is being stifled because of the way in which the government has centralised bureaucratic controls. Again, we learnt from the ABC people tonight that, despite what DEET says in estimates about freeing things up, the government is really making it harder. Money is being allocated, perhaps quite rightly, to growth areas with new populations and to disadvantaged areas, but the real problem is that the overall amount of money is not sufficient for what is needed.

Let us hope that the government starts to get the message on higher education and becomes less centralised and less bureaucratic and frees up this system. As indicated in the document, the current trends tend to cast some doubt that the government has learnt the lessons of the last few years. We urge it to return a lot more autonomy to the universities. It is only in this way that we will have a really first-class university system. At the moment it is being sent back in the other direction, and this should be of great concern to all Australians.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wanted to raise two matters on the adjournment. First, I made some statements to the Senate last year in relation to report No. 21 of the Auditor-General on Australian Government credit cards, which was quite a damning report on their use. During my discussion of that report I made mention of ATSIC as an organisation not training its people in the use of that card. I had been confused on that day because I had recently read an article in the Bulletin of 14 December reporting on Arch Bevis's report on Purchasing Australia and the use of credit cards. It was incorrectly reported in that article that ATSIC had no training in the use of those cards. I recently received a letter from the Chairman of ATSIC, Lois O'Donoghue, informing me that ATSIC does not use the credit cards and therefore has no requirement for the training. I repeated that which had been said in the Bulletin. I was wrong.

PARA.TAB: On 24 February I wrote to Ms O'Donoghue apologising unreservedly for that mistake, and further pointing out—not to try to lessen my guilt—that the cause of my misunderstanding was the article in the Bulletin wherein Mr Bevis had been reported as saying that ATSIC had no training and also noting a letter which the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) had written to the Bevis committee saying that ATSIC did not use the cards and therefore needed no training. I made the point that it is unusual that the minister had brought Mr Bevis's committee's attention to that fact and had still perpetuated the misunderstanding about ATSIC's use of the cards. So, I take this occasion to apologise on the public record and in the Senate to ATSIC for the mistake I made, and I do so unreservedly.

The other discussion point I raise in the adjournment debate tonight relates to an article I read in the West Australian newspaper on page 49; it was the property page from last Wednesday's edition of 23 February 1994. It draws the attention of readers, under a sort of gossip column part of the property page, to the fact that the former Premier of Western Australia, Dr Carmen Lawrence, has put her property in Lawler Street, Subiaco, on the market for a price of $395,000 through the local agency of Paxton Hoad.

I know Lawler Street well. It is a very nice, leafy street. The agents from Paxton Hoad—a most reputable and experienced firm of agents in the Subiaco area of Western Australia—describe the property thus:

SPEECH.PARA: three-bedroom home, warm and homely, with fireplaces in each bedroom, ornate ceilings and a neat and attractive garden with big trees and sundeck at the back.
As Niki Peinke, the agent in control of the property, said:
People fall over themselves to get into Lawler Street.

It is important to have a look at the context in which Dr Lawrence is actually selling her property in Subiaco. There are a couple of points. Dr Lawrence, being a candidate in the Fremantle by-election on 12 March, has one of those in mind, and that is that she is so certain that the people of Fremantle will elect her that she has put her place on the market and said she is looking around for a house in Fremantle. In amongst visiting nursing homes and doing other potential breaches of the electoral act she is also looking for a house in Fremantle.

PARA.TAB: I can assure honourable senators that the Liberal candidate in the by-election in the seat of Fremantle, Mr Geoff Horne, has made a commitment to the people of Fremantle that he will also move to the electorate if he is successful in getting elected. Being a former Army man and lately an investigator with the Australian Securities Commission, Geoff Horne is not so arrogant towards the people of Fremantle as to take for granted the decision that they will make on 12 March. He is prepared to wait, go down to Fremantle and put his case to the people door to door, community group by community group, and seek their support. If he gets it, he will, as a man of his word and an officer in the Australian Army, move down to Fremantle. He is not prepared to be so arrogant as to presume that the people of Fremantle will just vote for him because he has been anointed by Paul Keating and other members of the factional right wing machine over here in Canberra. He is prepared to seek the judgment of the people of Fremantle and to move to Fremantle if he is honoured with their vote and support.

One of the other important things about the $395,000 is that it brought to my mind the whole affair about Dr Carmen Lawrence when she had, for a period of nearly two years, an amount of $5,000 in her private bank account which had been paid into that bank account on the assumption that she was to take an overseas trip approximately two years before the last election. At about the time she had that amount paid into her personal account for overseas travel the former Premier, Peter Dowding, was over in Sweden. Carmen Lawrence and Stephen Smith—who is now the member for Perth—were plotting, while Mr Dowding was over in Sweden on a trade mission for Western Australia, to unseat Mr Dowding and install Carmen in the leadership of the Labor Party and therefore the premiership of Western Australia.

When the police investigated the payment of this $5,000, they found it had been sitting in her private bank account for two years; she did not take the trip because she had by then become the Premier,. The public explanation—and I presume to the police—was that she had forgotten that the amount was in her bank account.

We have to believe the fact that she says she has forgotten. She was the premier of Western Australia, and we have to look up to public figures, even though it is a bit hard to do it from time to time in this place. I see from the transcript of the WA Inc. royal commission that whenever Dr Lawrence was asked questions about crucial WA Inc dealings within the Western Australian cabinet—the PICL deal, and the whole range of dealings—her answer on a number of occasions was `I forget' or `I do not recall' or `I do not remember'. So the fact that the former Premier of Western Australia, now the Labor candidate in Fremantle, forgot that she had $5,000 in her account may not be unusual.

Many people in Lawler Street, Subiaco, live in very nice houses and probably have good jobs and good incomes, but not many of them would tell you that they would forget that they had $5,000 too much or too little in their accounts. The people in the seat of Fremantle have a lower average income and the average house price in that area is much lower—indeed, I would suggest the average house price in Fremantle is nearer to $100,000 than $300,000. Those people would certainly know whether they had $5,000 in their bank accounts. It is important for anyone who goes to Lawler Street and looks at Dr Lawrence's house to realise that, at a price of $395,000, there is a bit of negotiability. When Carmen Lawrence gets an offer of acceptance put on her desk, she will not notice whether the figure is $395,000 or $390,000. I encourage people who go to look at Dr Lawrence's house not to worry too much about $5,000—

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you in the real estate business?

—I was a real estate analyst in a former life. The other sad thing about this case is that when the police investigated the $5,000 that Carmen Lawrence forgot, she understood the police were investigating it and she wanted to throw some mud at the then Leader of the Opposition, Richard Court. She dragged up the whole sordid affair that involved Mr Easton and Penny Easton. Carmen Lawrence was party to having a petition laid on the table of the Legislative Assembly in Western Australia. The raising of that event again caused so much concern to Mr Easton's wife, Penny, that she took her own life the day following the tabling and, in a suicide note, blamed the political circumstances. I support the assertion of the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) that Dr Lawrence has blood on her hands. (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not intend to speak in this debate but, on behalf of the government, I cannot let the most extraordinary remarks of Senator Campbell go without the strongest protest. I do not know whether his remarks are unparliamentary. I have never been a great one to take objection to the language people use in parliament; one is judged by one's own performance. But it is an extraordinary allegation to say that a citizen of Australia, whether a member of parliament or not, has blood on her hands and then to directly relate that to a suicide. Unless Senator Campbell can absolutely substantiate it, it is one of the worst smears I have ever heard in 25 years of public life, whether in the Senate or as a party official looking at all sides of politics.

PARA.TAB: If what Senator Campbell has said is true—that Carmen Lawrence has blood on her hands and it is directly related to a person's death by suicide—I would have thought he should have gone to the police with that information. He is saying that Carmen Lawrence murdered this person. It is an extraordinary allegation. Senator Campbell has trumped it up and dropped it into an adjournment debate in this way because he thinks that under privilege the smear will work. It is an extraordinary smear. I will not ask him to withdraw it because I want him to be condemned for saying it. It is on the record. Senator Campbell in this Senate and the honourable member for O'Connor, Mr Tuckey, in the other place have put these things on the record.

Senator Campbell knows that if he said such a thing outside this place he would probably cop an action for defamation—probably criminal defamation. I have no doubt that he would be sued. I support parliamentary privilege because, in the last resort, it may be the only place where people can raise issues of human rights and criminal matters or expose corruption and so on. I have always supported that principle, but there is a responsibility on all senators and all House of Representatives members to understand it is a privilege given by the Australian people to elected members of parliament. It should not be abused in the way that Senator Campbell has most appallingly done.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
